<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>

<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">American singer, songwriter, and dancer (1958–2009)</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson_(disambiguation)" title="Michael Jackson (disambiguation)">Michael Jackson (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"King of Pop" redirects here. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/King_of_Pop_(disambiguation)" title="King of Pop (disambiguation)">King of Pop (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>

<p><b>Michael Joseph Jackson</b> (August 29, 1958 – June 25, 2009) was an American singer, songwriter, dancer, and philanthropist. Dubbed the "<a href="/wiki/Honorific_nicknames_in_popular_music" title="Honorific nicknames in popular music">King of Pop</a>", he is regarded as <a href="/wiki/Cultural_impact_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Cultural impact of Michael Jackson">one of the most significant cultural figures of the 20th century</a>. Over a four-decade career, his contributions to music, dance, and fashion, along with his publicized personal life, made him a global figure in <a href="/wiki/Popular_culture" title="Popular culture">popular culture</a>. Jackson influenced artists across many music genres; through stage and video performances, he popularized complicated dance moves such as the <a href="/wiki/Moonwalk_(dance)" title="Moonwalk (dance)">moonwalk</a>, to which he gave the name, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Robot_(dance)" title="Robot (dance)">robot</a>. He is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_awards_and_nominations_received_by_Michael_Jackson" title="List of awards and nominations received by Michael Jackson">most awarded individual music artist</a> in history.
</p><p>The eighth child of the <a href="/wiki/Jackson_family" title="Jackson family">Jackson family</a>, Jackson made his professional debut in 1964 with his older brothers <a href="/wiki/Jackie_Jackson" title="Jackie Jackson">Jackie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tito_Jackson" title="Tito Jackson">Tito</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jermaine_Jackson" title="Jermaine Jackson">Jermaine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Marlon_Jackson" title="Marlon Jackson">Marlon</a> as a member of <a href="/wiki/The_Jackson_5" title="The Jackson 5">the Jackson 5</a> (later known as the Jacksons). Jackson began his solo career in 1971 while at <a href="/wiki/Motown" title="Motown">Motown Records</a>. He became a solo star with his 1979 album <i><a href="/wiki/Off_the_Wall" title="Off the Wall">Off the Wall</a></i>. His <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson_videography" title="Michael Jackson videography">music videos</a>, including those for "<a href="/wiki/Beat_It" title="Beat It">Beat It</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Billie_Jean" title="Billie Jean">Billie Jean</a>", and "<a href="/wiki/Thriller_(song)" title="Thriller (song)">Thriller</a>" from his 1982 album <i><a href="/wiki/Thriller_(album)" title="Thriller (album)">Thriller</a></i>, are credited with breaking <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anti-black_racism_in_the_United_States" title="Anti-black racism in the United States">racial barriers</a> and transforming the medium into an artform and promotional tool. He helped propel the success of <a href="/wiki/MTV" title="MTV">MTV</a> and continued to innovate with videos for the albums <i><a href="/wiki/Bad_(album)" title="Bad (album)">Bad</a></i> (1987), <i><a href="/wiki/Dangerous_(Michael_Jackson_album)" title="Dangerous (Michael Jackson album)">Dangerous</a></i> (1991), and <i><a href="/wiki/HIStory:_Past,_Present_and_Future,_Book_I" title="HIStory: Past, Present and Future, Book I">HIStory: Past, Present and Future, Book I</a></i> (1995). <i>Thriller</i> became the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_albums" title="List of best-selling albums">best-selling album of all time</a>, while <i>Bad</i> was the first album to produce five U.S. <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100"><i>Billboard</i> Hot 100</a> number-one singles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1"><a href="#cite_note-1">[nb 1]</a></sup>
</p><p>From the late 1980s, Jackson became a figure of controversy and speculation due to his <a href="/wiki/Health_and_appearance_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Health and appearance of Michael Jackson">changing appearance</a>, <a href="/wiki/Personal_relationships_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Personal relationships of Michael Jackson">relationships</a>, behavior, and lifestyle. In 1993, he was <a href="/wiki/1993_child_sexual_abuse_accusations_against_Michael_Jackson" title="1993 child sexual abuse accusations against Michael Jackson">accused of sexually abusing the child</a> of a family friend. The lawsuit was settled out of civil court; Jackson was not indicted due to lack of evidence. In 2005, he was <a href="/wiki/Trial_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Trial of Michael Jackson">tried and acquitted</a> of further child sexual abuse allegations and several other charges. The <a href="/wiki/FBI_files_on_Michael_Jackson" title="FBI files on Michael Jackson">FBI</a> found no evidence of criminal conduct on Jackson's behalf in either case. In 2009, while preparing for a series of comeback concerts, <a href="/wiki/This_Is_It_(concert_residency)" title="This Is It (concert residency)">This Is It</a>, Jackson <a href="/wiki/Death_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Death of Michael Jackson">died</a> from an overdose of <a href="/wiki/Propofol" title="Propofol">propofol</a> administered by his personal physician, <a href="/wiki/Conrad_Murray" title="Conrad Murray">Conrad Murray</a>, who was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/California_v._Murray" title="California v. Murray">convicted in 2011</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Involuntary_manslaughter" title="Involuntary manslaughter">involuntary manslaughter</a>.
</p><p>Jackson is one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_music_artists" title="List of best-selling music artists">best-selling music artists</a> of all time, with estimated sales of over 400<span class="nowrap"> </span>million records worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10"><a href="#cite_note-10">[nb 2]</a></sup> He had 13 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_artists_by_number_of_Billboard_Hot_100_number-one_singles" title="List of artists by number of Billboard Hot 100 number-one singles"><i>Billboard</i> Hot 100 number-one singles</a> (more than any other male artist in the Hot 100 era) and was the first artist to have a top-ten single in the <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100 in five different decades. He is regarded by the <a href="/wiki/Recording_Industry_Association_of_America" title="Recording Industry Association of America">RIAA</a> as the highest-selling individual music artist of all time worldwide. His honors include 15 <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Awards" title="Grammy Awards">Grammy Awards</a>, 6 <a href="/wiki/Brit_Awards" title="Brit Awards">Brit Awards</a>, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award" title="Golden Globe Award">Golden Globe Award</a>, and 39 <a href="/wiki/Guinness_World_Records" title="Guinness World Records">Guinness World Records</a>, including the "Most Successful Entertainer of All Time". Jackson's inductions include the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Rock_and_Roll_Hall_of_Fame_inductees" title="List of Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inductees">Rock and Roll Hall of Fame</a> (twice), the <a href="/wiki/Vocal_Group_Hall_of_Fame" title="Vocal Group Hall of Fame">Vocal Group Hall of Fame</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Songwriters_Hall_of_Fame" title="Songwriters Hall of Fame">Songwriters Hall of Fame</a>, the <a href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_Dance_and_Hall_of_Fame" title="National Museum of Dance and Hall of Fame">Dance Hall of Fame</a> (the only recording artist to be inducted), and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rhythm_and_Blues_Music_Hall_of_Fame" title="Rhythm and Blues Music Hall of Fame">Rhythm and Blues Music Hall of Fame</a>. In 2016, his estate earned $825<span class="nowrap"> </span>million, the highest yearly amount for a celebrity ever recorded by <i><a href="/wiki/Forbes" title="Forbes">Forbes</a></i>.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

</li>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Life_and_career">Life and career</span></h2>
<h3><span id="Early_life_and_the_Jackson_5_.281958.E2.80.931975.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life_and_the_Jackson_5_(1958–1975)">Early life and the Jackson 5 (1958–1975)</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2300_Jackson_Street_Yuksel.jpg"><img alt="The single-story house has white walls, two windows, a central white door with a black door frame, and a black roof. In front of the house there is a walkway and multiple colored flowers and memorabilia." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3456" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/2300_Jackson_Street_Yuksel.jpg/220px-2300_Jackson_Street_Yuksel.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/2300_Jackson_Street_Yuksel.jpg/330px-2300_Jackson_Street_Yuksel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/2300_Jackson_Street_Yuksel.jpg/440px-2300_Jackson_Street_Yuksel.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2300_Jackson_Street_Yuksel.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jackson's childhood home in <a href="/wiki/Gary,_Indiana" title="Gary, Indiana">Gary, Indiana</a>, pictured in March 2010</div></div></div>
<p>Michael Joseph Jackson<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-certificate_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-certificate-11">[9]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-allmusic-12">[10]</a></sup> was born in <a href="/wiki/Gary,_Indiana" title="Gary, Indiana">Gary, Indiana</a>, on August 29, 1958.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Barnes_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-Barnes-13">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[12]</a></sup> He was the eighth of ten children in the <a href="/wiki/Jackson_family" title="Jackson family">Jackson family</a>, a working-class <a href="/wiki/African_Americans" title="African Americans">African-American</a> family living in a two-bedroom house on Jackson Street.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJackson200926_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJackson200926-15">[13]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYoung200918_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYoung200918-16">[14]</a></sup> His mother, <a href="/wiki/Katherine_Jackson" title="Katherine Jackson">Katherine Esther Jackson</a> (<i>née</i> Scruse), played clarinet and piano, had aspired to be a <a href="/wiki/Country_music" title="Country music">country-and-western</a> performer, and worked part-time at <a href="/wiki/Sears" title="Sears">Sears</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYoung200917,_19_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYoung200917,_19-17">[15]</a></sup> She was a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witness" title="Jehovah's Witness">Jehovah's Witness</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-monstrous_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-monstrous-18">[16]</a></sup> His father, <a href="/wiki/Joe_Jackson_(manager)" title="Joe Jackson (manager)">Joseph Walter "Joe" Jackson</a>, a former boxer, was a crane operator at <a href="/wiki/U.S._Steel" title="U.S. Steel">U.S. Steel</a> and played guitar with a local <a href="/wiki/Rhythm_and_blues" title="Rhythm and blues">rhythm and blues</a> band, the Falcons, to supplement the family's income.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Obit_Guardian_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-Obit_Guardian-19">[17]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYoung200918–19_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYoung200918–19-20">[18]</a></sup> Joe's great-grandfather, July "Jack" Gale, was a US Army <a href="/wiki/Cavalry_scout" title="Cavalry scout">scout</a>; family lore held that he was also a Native American <a href="/wiki/Medicine_man" title="Medicine man">medicine man</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKnopper20166._Note:_No_tribal_affiliation_named_in_source_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKnopper20166._Note:_No_tribal_affiliation_named_in_source-21">[19]</a></sup> Michael grew up with three sisters (<a href="/wiki/Rebbie_Jackson" title="Rebbie Jackson">Rebbie</a>, <a href="/wiki/La_Toya_Jackson" title="La Toya Jackson">La Toya</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Janet_Jackson" title="Janet Jackson">Janet</a>) and five brothers (<a href="/wiki/Jackie_Jackson" title="Jackie Jackson">Jackie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tito_Jackson" title="Tito Jackson">Tito</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jermaine_Jackson" title="Jermaine Jackson">Jermaine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marlon_Jackson" title="Marlon Jackson">Marlon</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Randy_Jackson_(The_Jacksons)" title="Randy Jackson (The Jacksons)">Randy</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Obit_Guardian_19-1"><a href="#cite_note-Obit_Guardian-19">[17]</a></sup> A sixth brother, Marlon's twin Brandon, died shortly after birth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[20]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1964, Michael and Marlon joined the Jackson Brothers—a band formed by their father which included Jackie, Tito, and Jermaine—as backup musicians playing <a href="/wiki/Conga" title="Conga">congas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tambourine" title="Tambourine">tambourine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[21]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[22]</a></sup> Michael said his father told him he had a "fat nose",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbcnews_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbcnews-25">[23]</a></sup> and physically and emotionally abused him during rehearsals. He recalled that Joe often sat in a chair with a belt in his hand as he and his siblings rehearsed, ready to punish any mistakes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-monstrous_18-1"><a href="#cite_note-monstrous-18">[16]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewis_Jones2005165–168_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewis_Jones2005165–168-26">[24]</a></sup> Joe acknowledged that he regularly whipped Michael.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[25]</a></sup> Katherine said that although whipping came to be considered abuse, it was a common way to discipline children when Michael was growing up.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[26]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[27]</a></sup> Jackie, Tito, Jermaine and Marlon denied that their father was abusive and said that the whippings, which were harder on Michael because he was younger, kept them disciplined and out of trouble.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[28]</a></sup> Michael said his youth was lonely and isolated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYoung200924_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYoung200924-31">[29]</a></sup>
</p><p>Later in 1964, Michael began sharing lead vocals with Jermaine, and the group's name was changed to <a href="/wiki/The_Jackson_5" title="The Jackson 5">the Jackson 5</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[30]</a></sup> In 1965, the group won a talent show; Michael performed the dance to <a href="/wiki/Robert_Parker_(singer)" title="Robert Parker (singer)">Robert Parker</a>'s 1965 song "<a href="/wiki/Barefootin%27_(song)" title="Barefootin' (song)">Barefootin'</a>" and sang <a href="/wiki/The_Temptations" title="The Temptations">the Temptations</a>' "<a href="/wiki/My_Girl_(The_Temptations_song)" title="My Girl (The Temptations song)">My Girl</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli200913–14_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli200913–14-33">[31]</a></sup> From 1966 to 1968, the Jacksons 5 toured the <a href="/wiki/Midwestern_United_States" title="Midwestern United States">Midwest</a>; they frequently played at a string of black clubs known as the <a href="/wiki/Chitlin%27_Circuit" title="Chitlin' Circuit">Chitlin' Circuit</a> as the opening act for artists such as <a href="/wiki/Sam_%26_Dave" title="Sam &amp; Dave">Sam &amp; Dave</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_O%27Jays" title="The O'Jays">the O'Jays</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gladys_Knight" title="Gladys Knight">Gladys Knight</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Etta_James" title="Etta James">Etta James</a>. The Jackson 5 also performed at clubs and cocktail lounges, where <a href="/wiki/Striptease" title="Striptease">striptease</a> shows were featured, and at local auditoriums and high school dances.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYoung200921–22_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYoung200921–22-34">[32]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[33]</a></sup> In August 1967, while touring the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_United_States" title="Eastern United States">East Coast</a>, they won a weekly amateur night concert at the <a href="/wiki/Apollo_Theater" title="Apollo Theater">Apollo Theater</a> in <a href="/wiki/Harlem" title="Harlem">Harlem</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYoung200922_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYoung200922-36">[34]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jackson_5_tv_special_1972.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="691" data-file-width="890" decoding="async" height="171" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Jackson_5_tv_special_1972.JPG/220px-Jackson_5_tv_special_1972.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Jackson_5_tv_special_1972.JPG/330px-Jackson_5_tv_special_1972.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Jackson_5_tv_special_1972.JPG/440px-Jackson_5_tv_special_1972.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jackson_5_tv_special_1972.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jackson (center) as a member of the Jackson 5 in 1972. The group were among the first <a href="/wiki/African_Americans" title="African Americans">African American</a> performers to attain a crossover following.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[35]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The Jackson 5 recorded several songs for a Gary record label, <a href="/wiki/Steeltown_Records" title="Steeltown Records">Steeltown Records</a>; their first single, "<a href="/wiki/Big_Boy_(song)" title="Big Boy (song)">Big Boy</a>", was released in 1968.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYoung200921_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYoung200921-38">[36]</a></sup> Bobby Taylor of <a href="/wiki/Bobby_Taylor_%26_the_Vancouvers" title="Bobby Taylor &amp; the Vancouvers">Bobby Taylor &amp; the Vancouvers</a> brought the Jackson 5 to <a href="/wiki/Motown" title="Motown">Motown</a> after they opened for Taylor at Chicago's <a href="/wiki/Regal_Theater,_Chicago" title="Regal Theater, Chicago">Regal Theater</a> in 1968. Taylor produced some of their early Motown recordings, including a version of "<a href="/wiki/Who%27s_Lovin%27_You" title="Who's Lovin' You">Who's Lovin' You</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[37]</a></sup> After signing with Motown, the Jackson family relocated to Los Angeles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli200959–69_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli200959–69-40">[38]</a></sup> In 1969, Motown executives decided <a href="/wiki/Diana_Ross" title="Diana Ross">Diana Ross</a> should introduce the Jackson 5 to the public—partly to bolster her career in television—sending off what was considered Motown's last product of its "production line".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[39]</a></sup> The Jackson 5 made their first television appearance in 1969 in the <a href="/wiki/Miss_Black_America" title="Miss Black America">Miss Black America</a> pageant, performing a cover of "<a href="/wiki/It%27s_Your_Thing" title="It's Your Thing">It's Your Thing</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[40]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stone" title="Rolling Stone">Rolling Stone</a></i> later described the young Michael as "a prodigy" with "overwhelming musical gifts" who "quickly emerged as the main draw and lead singer".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bio_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bio-43">[41]</a></sup>
</p><p>In January 1970, "<a href="/wiki/I_Want_You_Back" title="I Want You Back">I Want You Back</a>" became the first Jackson 5 song to reach number one on the US <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100"><i>Billboard</i> Hot 100</a>; it stayed there for four weeks. Three more singles with Motown topped the chart: "<a href="/wiki/ABC_(The_Jackson_5_song)" title="ABC (The Jackson 5 song)">ABC</a>", "<a href="/wiki/The_Love_You_Save" title="The Love You Save">The Love You Save</a>", and "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/I%27ll_Be_There_(The_Jackson_5_song)" title="I'll Be There (The Jackson 5 song)">I'll Be There</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[42]</a></sup> In May 1971, the Jackson family moved into a large house at <a href="/wiki/Hayvenhurst" title="Hayvenhurst">Hayvenhurst</a>, a two-acre estate in <a href="/wiki/Encino,_Los_Angeles" title="Encino, Los Angeles">Encino, California</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli200981–82_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli200981–82-45">[43]</a></sup> During this period, Michael developed from a child performer into a <a href="/wiki/Teen_idol" title="Teen idol">teen idol</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYoung200925_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYoung200925-46">[44]</a></sup> Between 1972 and 1975, he released four solo studio albums with Motown: <i><a href="/wiki/Got_to_Be_There" title="Got to Be There">Got to Be There</a></i> (1972), <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ben_(album)" title="Ben (album)">Ben</a></i> (1972), <i><a href="/wiki/Music_%26_Me" title="Music &amp; Me">Music &amp; Me</a></i> (1973), and <i><a href="/wiki/Forever,_Michael" title="Forever, Michael">Forever, Michael</a></i> (1975).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McNulty_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-McNulty-47">[45]</a></sup> "<a href="/wiki/Got_to_Be_There_(song)" title="Got to Be There (song)">Got to Be There</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Ben_(song)" title="Ben (song)">Ben</a>", the title tracks from his first two solo albums, sold well as singles, as did a cover of <a href="/wiki/Bobby_Day" title="Bobby Day">Bobby Day</a>'s "<a href="/wiki/Rockin%27_Robin_(song)" title="Rockin' Robin (song)">Rockin' Robin</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli200998–99_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli200998–99-48">[46]</a></sup>
</p><p>Michael maintained ties to the Jackson 5.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McNulty_47-1"><a href="#cite_note-McNulty-47">[45]</a></sup> The Jackson 5 were later described as "a cutting-edge example of black <a href="/wiki/Crossover_music" title="Crossover music">crossover artists</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[47]</a></sup> They were frustrated by Motown's refusal to allow them creative input.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[48]</a></sup> Jackson's performance of their top five single "<a href="/wiki/Dancing_Machine" title="Dancing Machine">Dancing Machine</a>" on <i><a href="/wiki/Soul_Train" title="Soul Train">Soul Train</a></i> popularized the <a href="/wiki/Robot_(dance)" title="Robot (dance)">robot dance</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMansour2005403_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMansour2005403-51">[49]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Move_to_Epic_and_Off_the_Wall_.281975.E2.80.931981.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Move_to_Epic_and_Off_the_Wall_(1975–1981)">Move to Epic and <i>Off the Wall</i> (1975–1981)</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jackson_siblings_1977.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="641" data-file-width="662" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Jackson_siblings_1977.jpg/170px-Jackson_siblings_1977.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Jackson_siblings_1977.jpg/255px-Jackson_siblings_1977.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Jackson_siblings_1977.jpg/340px-Jackson_siblings_1977.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jackson_siblings_1977.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Jackson siblings in 1977, without Jermaine. From left, back row: <a href="/wiki/Jackie_Jackson" title="Jackie Jackson">Jackie</a>, Michael, <a href="/wiki/Tito_Jackson" title="Tito Jackson">Tito</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marlon_Jackson" title="Marlon Jackson">Marlon</a>. Middle row: <a href="/wiki/Randy_Jackson_(Jacksons_singer)" title="Randy Jackson (Jacksons singer)">Randy</a>, <a href="/wiki/La_Toya_Jackson" title="La Toya Jackson">La Toya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rebbie_Jackson" title="Rebbie Jackson">Rebbie</a>. Front row: <a href="/wiki/Janet_Jackson" title="Janet Jackson">Janet</a> (1977).</div></div></div>
<p>The Jackson 5 left Motown in 1975, signing with <a href="/wiki/Epic_Records" title="Epic Records">Epic Records</a> and renaming themselves the Jacksons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[50]</a></sup> Their younger brother Randy joined the band around this time; Jermaine stayed with Motown and pursued a solo career.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009138–144_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009138–144-53">[51]</a></sup> The Jacksons continued to tour internationally, and released six more albums between 1976 and 1984. Michael, the group's main songwriter during this time, wrote songs such as "<a href="/wiki/Shake_Your_Body_(Down_to_the_Ground)" title="Shake Your Body (Down to the Ground)">Shake Your Body (Down to the Ground)</a>" (1978), "<a href="/wiki/This_Place_Hotel" title="This Place Hotel">This Place Hotel</a>" (1980), and "<a href="/wiki/Can_You_Feel_It_(The_Jacksons_song)" title="Can You Feel It (The Jacksons song)">Can You Feel It</a>" (1980).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1977, Jackson moved to New York City to star as the <a href="/wiki/Scarecrow_(Oz)" title="Scarecrow (Oz)">Scarecrow</a> in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wiz_(film)" title="The Wiz (film)">The Wiz</a></i>, a musical film directed by <a href="/wiki/Sidney_Lumet" title="Sidney Lumet">Sidney Lumet</a>, alongside <a href="/wiki/Diana_Ross" title="Diana Ross">Diana Ross</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nipsey_Russell" title="Nipsey Russell">Nipsey Russell</a>, and Ted Ross.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[53]</a></sup> The film was a box-office failure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009178–179_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009178–179-56">[54]</a></sup> Its score was arranged by <a href="/wiki/Quincy_Jones" title="Quincy Jones">Quincy Jones</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronson2003207_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronson2003207-57">[55]</a></sup> who later produced three of Jackson's solo albums.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Who's_Bad_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-Who's_Bad-58">[56]</a></sup> During his time in New York, Jackson frequented the <a href="/wiki/Studio_54" title="Studio 54">Studio 54</a> nightclub, where he heard early <a href="/wiki/Hip_hop_music" title="Hip hop music">hip hop</a>; this influenced his <a href="/wiki/Beatboxing" title="Beatboxing">beatboxing</a> on future tracks such as "<a href="/wiki/Working_Day_and_Night" title="Working Day and Night">Working Day and Night</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[57]</a></sup> In 1978, Jackson broke his nose during a dance routine. A <a href="/wiki/Rhinoplasty" title="Rhinoplasty">rhinoplasty</a> led to breathing difficulties that later affected his career. He was referred to <a href="/wiki/Steven_Hoefflin" title="Steven Hoefflin">Steven Hoefflin</a>, who performed Jackson's operations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009205–210_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009205–210-60">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jackson's fifth solo album, <i><a href="/wiki/Off_the_Wall" title="Off the Wall">Off the Wall</a></i> (1979), established him as a solo performer and helped him move from the <a href="/wiki/Bubblegum_music" title="Bubblegum music">bubblegum</a> pop of his youth to more complex sounds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYoung200925_46-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYoung200925-46">[44]</a></sup> It produced four top 10 entries in the US: "<a href="/wiki/Off_the_Wall_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Off the Wall (Michael Jackson song)">Off the Wall</a>", "<a href="/wiki/She%27s_Out_of_My_Life" title="She's Out of My Life">She's Out of My Life</a>", and the chart-topping singles "<a href="/wiki/Don%27t_Stop_%27Til_You_Get_Enough" title="Don't Stop 'Til You Get Enough">Don't Stop 'Til You Get Enough</a>" and "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rock_with_You_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Rock with You (Michael Jackson song)">Rock with You</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FourUSTop10s_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-FourUSTop10s-61">[59]</a></sup> The album reached number three on the US <a href="/wiki/Billboard_200" title="Billboard 200"><i>Billboard</i> 200</a> and sold over 20<span class="nowrap"> </span>million copies worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[60]</a></sup> In 1980, Jackson won three <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/American_Music_Award" title="American Music Award">American Music Awards</a> for his solo work: Favorite Soul/R&amp;B Album, Favorite Soul/R&amp;B Male Artist, and Favorite Soul/R&amp;B Single for "Don't Stop 'Til You Get Enough".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[61]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[62]</a></sup> He also won a Grammy Award for Best Male R&amp;B Vocal Performance for 1979 with "Don't Stop 'Til You Get Enough".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-grammy_mj_65-0"><a href="#cite_note-grammy_mj-65">[63]</a></sup> In 1981, Jackson was the American Music Awards winner for Favorite Soul/R&amp;B Album and Favorite Soul/R&amp;B Male Artist.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[64]</a></sup> Jackson felt <i>Off the Wall</i> should have made a bigger impact, and was determined to exceed expectations with his next release.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009188_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009188-67">[65]</a></sup> In 1980, he secured the highest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royalties" title="Royalties">royalty</a> rate in the music industry: 37 percent of wholesale album profit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009191_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009191-68">[66]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Thriller_and_Motown_25:_Yesterday.2C_Today.2C_Forever_.281982.E2.80.931983.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Thriller_and_Motown_25:_Yesterday,_Today,_Forever_(1982–1983)"><i>Thriller</i> and <i>Motown 25: Yesterday, Today, Forever</i> (1982–1983)</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson%27s_Glove_and_Cardigan.jpg"><img alt="A sparkly jacket and gloves, displayed inside a transparent vertical tube." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="450" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Michael_Jackson%27s_Glove_and_Cardigan.jpg/170px-Michael_Jackson%27s_Glove_and_Cardigan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Michael_Jackson%27s_Glove_and_Cardigan.jpg/255px-Michael_Jackson%27s_Glove_and_Cardigan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Michael_Jackson%27s_Glove_and_Cardigan.jpg/340px-Michael_Jackson%27s_Glove_and_Cardigan.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson%27s_Glove_and_Cardigan.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The sequined jacket and white glove worn by Jackson at <i><a href="/wiki/Motown_25:_Yesterday,_Today,_Forever" title="Motown 25: Yesterday, Today, Forever">Motown 25: Yesterday, Today, Forever</a></i>. <i><a href="/wiki/British_Vogue" title="British Vogue">British Vogue</a></i> called Jackson "a fashion pioneer [...] who gave new meaning to <a href="/wiki/Moonwalk_(dance)" title="Moonwalk (dance)">moonwalking</a>, immortalised solitary, [and] sparkly gloves".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[67]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Jackson recorded with <a href="/wiki/Queen_(band)" title="Queen (band)">Queen</a> singer <a href="/wiki/Freddie_Mercury" title="Freddie Mercury">Freddie Mercury</a> from 1981 to 1983, recording demos of "<a href="/wiki/State_of_Shock_(song)" title="State of Shock (song)">State of Shock</a>", "Victory" and "<a href="/wiki/There_Must_Be_More_to_Life_Than_This" title="There Must Be More to Life Than This">There Must Be More to Life Than This</a>". The recordings were intended for an album of duets but, according to Queen's manager <a href="/wiki/Jim_Beach" title="Jim Beach">Jim Beach</a>, the relationship soured when Jackson brought a <a href="/wiki/Llama" title="Llama">llama</a> into the recording studio,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[68]</a></sup> and Jackson was upset by Mercury's drug use.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[69]</a></sup> The songs were released in 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Greene_72-0"><a href="#cite_note-Greene-72">[70]</a></sup> Jackson went on to record "State of Shock" with <a href="/wiki/Mick_Jagger" title="Mick Jagger">Mick Jagger</a> for the Jacksons' album <i><a href="/wiki/Victory_(The_Jacksons_album)" title="Victory (The Jacksons album)">Victory</a></i> (1984).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[71]</a></sup> In 1982, Jackson contributed "Someone in the Dark" to the <a href="/wiki/E.T._the_Extra-Terrestrial_(album)" title="E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial (album)">audiobook for the film <i>E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial</i></a>. Jackson's sixth album, <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Thriller_(Michael_Jackson_album)" title="Thriller (Michael Jackson album)">Thriller</a></i>, was released in late 1982. It was the best-selling album worldwide in 1983,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[72]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[73]</a></sup> and became the best-selling album of all time in the US<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[74]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_albums" title="List of best-selling albums">best-selling album of all time worldwide</a>, selling an estimated <span class="nowrap">70 million</span> copies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[75]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[76]</a></sup> It topped the <i>Billboard</i> 200 chart for 37 weeks and was in the top 10 of the 200 for 80 consecutive weeks. It was the first album to produce seven <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100 top-10 singles, including "<a href="/wiki/Billie_Jean" title="Billie Jean">Billie Jean</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Beat_It" title="Beat It">Beat It</a>", and "<a href="/wiki/Wanna_Be_Startin%27_Somethin%27" title="Wanna Be Startin' Somethin'">Wanna Be Startin' Somethin'</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewis_Jones200547_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewis_Jones200547-79">[77]</a></sup>
</p><p>On March 25, 1983, Jackson reunited with his brothers for <i><a href="/wiki/Motown_25:_Yesterday,_Today,_Forever" title="Motown 25: Yesterday, Today, Forever">Motown 25: Yesterday, Today, Forever</a></i>, an NBC television special. The show aired on May 16 to an estimated audience of <span class="nowrap">47 million</span>, and featured the Jacksons and other Motown stars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[78]</a></sup> Jackson's solo performance of "Billie Jean" earned him his first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emmy_Award" title="Emmy Award">Emmy Award</a> nomination.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-emmys.tv_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-emmys.tv-81">[79]</a></sup> Wearing a glove decorated with <a href="/wiki/Rhinestone" title="Rhinestone">rhinestones</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[80]</a></sup> he debuted his <a href="/wiki/Moonwalk_(dance)" title="Moonwalk (dance)">moonwalk dance</a>, which <a href="/wiki/Jeffrey_Daniel" title="Jeffrey Daniel">Jeffrey Daniel</a> had taught him three years earlier, and it became his signature dance in his repertoire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Daniel_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-Daniel-83">[81]</a></sup> Jackson had originally turned down the invitation to the show, believing he had been doing too much television. But at the request of Motown founder <a href="/wiki/Berry_Gordy" title="Berry Gordy">Berry Gordy</a>, he performed in exchange for an opportunity to do a solo performance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009234–237_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009234–237-84">[82]</a></sup> <i>Rolling Stone</i> reporter Mikal Gilmore called the performance "extraordinary".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYoung200925_46-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYoung200925-46">[44]</a></sup> Jackson's performance drew comparisons to <a href="/wiki/Elvis_Presley" title="Elvis Presley">Elvis Presley</a>'s and <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">the Beatles</a>' appearances on <i><a href="/wiki/The_Ed_Sullivan_Show" title="The Ed Sullivan Show">The Ed Sullivan Show</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009238–241_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009238–241-85">[83]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Anna_Kisselgoff" title="Anna Kisselgoff">Anna Kisselgoff</a> of <i>The New York Times</i> praised the perfect timing and technique involved in the dance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[84]</a></sup> Gordy described being "mesmerized" by the performance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[85]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the <a href="/wiki/26th_Annual_Grammy_Awards" title="26th Annual Grammy Awards">26th Annual Grammy Awards</a>, <i>Thriller</i> won eight awards, and Jackson won an award for the <i>E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial</i> storybook. Winning eight Grammys in one ceremony is a record he holds with the band <a href="/wiki/Santana_(band)" title="Santana (band)">Santana</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-grammy_mj_65-1"><a href="#cite_note-grammy_mj-65">[63]</a></sup> Jackson and Quincy Jones won the award for Producer of the Year (Non-Classical). <i>Thriller</i> won Album of the Year (with Jackson as the album's artist and Jones as its co-producer), and the single won Best Pop Vocal Performance (Male) award for Jackson. "Beat It" won Record of the Year and Best Rock Vocal Performance (Male). "Billie Jean" won two Grammy awards: Best R&amp;B Song and Best R&amp;B Vocal Performance (Male), with Jackson as songwriter and singer respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-grammy_mj_65-2"><a href="#cite_note-grammy_mj-65">[63]</a></sup> <i>Thriller</i> won the Grammy for Best Engineered Recording (Non Classical), acknowledging <a href="/wiki/Bruce_Swedien" title="Bruce Swedien">Bruce Swedien</a> for his work on the album.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bruce_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bruce-88">[86]</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/American_Music_Awards_of_1984" title="American Music Awards of 1984">11th Annual American Music Awards</a>, Jackson won another eight awards and became the youngest artist to win the Award of Merit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Awards_1984_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-Awards_1984-89">[87]</a></sup> He also won Favorite Male Artist, Favorite Soul/R&amp;B Artist, and Favorite Pop/Rock Artist. "Beat It" won Favorite Soul/R&amp;B Video, Favorite Pop/Rock Video and Favorite Pop/Rock Single. The album won Favorite Soul/R&amp;B Album and Favorite Pop/Rock Album.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Awards_1984_89-1"><a href="#cite_note-Awards_1984-89">[87]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[88]</a></sup> <i>Thriller</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s sales doubled after the release of an extended music video, <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson%27s_Thriller_(music_video)" title="Michael Jackson's Thriller (music video)"><i>Michael Jackson's Thriller</i></a>, which sees Jackson dancing with a horde of zombies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[89]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Griffin_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-Griffin-92">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p>The success transformed Jackson into a dominant force in global pop culture, and cemented his status as the "king of pop".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Griffin_92-1"><a href="#cite_note-Griffin-92">[90]</a></sup> Jackson had the highest royalty rate in the music industry at that point, with about $2 for every album sold (equivalent to $5 in 2021), and was making record-breaking profits. Dolls modeled after Jackson appeared in stores in May 1984 for $12 each.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Time_93-0"><a href="#cite_note-Time-93">[91]</a></sup> In the same year, <i>The Making of Michael Jackson's Thriller</i>, a documentary about the music video, won a Grammy for Best Music Video (Longform).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-grammy_mj_65-3"><a href="#cite_note-grammy_mj-65">[63]</a></sup> <i>Time</i> described Jackson's influence at that point as "star of records, radio, rock video. A one-man rescue team for the music business. A songwriter who sets the beat for a decade. A dancer with the fanciest feet on the street. A singer who cuts across all boundaries of taste and style and color too."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Time_93-1"><a href="#cite_note-Time-93">[91]</a></sup> <i>The New York Times</i> wrote "in the world of pop music, there is Michael Jackson and there is everybody else".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[92]</a></sup>
</p><p>
On May 14, 1984, President <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a> gave Jackson an award recognizing his support of alcohol and drug abuse charities,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009304–307_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009304–307-95">[93]</a></sup> and in recognition of his support for the <a href="/wiki/Ad_Council" title="Ad Council">Ad Council</a>'s and the <a href="/wiki/National_Highway_Traffic_Safety_Administration" title="National Highway Traffic Safety Administration">National Highway Traffic Safety Administration</a>'s Drunk Driving Prevention campaign. Jackson allowed the campaign to use "Beat It" for its public service announcements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[94]</a></sup><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style></p><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:254px;max-width:254px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:252px;max-width:252px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Reagans_with_Michael_Jackson.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="372" data-file-width="575" decoding="async" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Reagans_with_Michael_Jackson.jpg/250px-Reagans_with_Michael_Jackson.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Reagans_with_Michael_Jackson.jpg/375px-Reagans_with_Michael_Jackson.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Reagans_with_Michael_Jackson.jpg/500px-Reagans_with_Michael_Jackson.jpg 2x" width="250"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">President Ronald Reagan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nancy_Reagan" title="Nancy Reagan">First Lady Nancy Reagan</a> shortly before presenting Jackson with the award at the <a href="/wiki/White_House" title="White House">White House</a> on May 14, 1984</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:252px;max-width:252px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_Reagan_Pete_Souza_1984.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="571" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Michael_Jackson_Reagan_Pete_Souza_1984.jpg/250px-Michael_Jackson_Reagan_Pete_Souza_1984.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Michael_Jackson_Reagan_Pete_Souza_1984.jpg/375px-Michael_Jackson_Reagan_Pete_Souza_1984.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Michael_Jackson_Reagan_Pete_Souza_1984.jpg/500px-Michael_Jackson_Reagan_Pete_Souza_1984.jpg 2x" width="250"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Jackson inside the White House with the Reagans</div></div></div></div></div>
<h3><span id="Pepsi_incident_and_other_commercial_activities_.281984.E2.80.931985.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Pepsi_incident_and_other_commercial_activities_(1984–1985)">Pepsi incident and other commercial activities (1984–1985)</span></h3>
<p>In November 1983, Jackson and his brothers partnered with <a href="/wiki/PepsiCo" title="PepsiCo">PepsiCo</a> in a $5<span class="nowrap"> </span>million promotional deal that broke records for a celebrity endorsement (equivalent to $13,603,408 in 2021). The first Pepsi campaign, which ran in the US from 1983 to 1984 and launched its "New Generation" theme, included tour sponsorship, public relations events, and in-store displays. Jackson helped to create the advertisement, and suggested using his song "Billie Jean", with revised lyrics, as its <a href="/wiki/Jingle" title="Jingle">jingle</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herrera2_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-Herrera2-97">[95]</a></sup>
</p><p>On January 27, 1984, Michael and other members of the Jacksons filmed a Pepsi commercial overseen by <a href="/wiki/Phil_Dusenberry" title="Phil Dusenberry">Phil Dusenberry</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[96]</a></sup> a <a href="/wiki/BBDO" title="BBDO">BBDO</a> ad agency executive, and <a href="/wiki/Alan_Pottasch" title="Alan Pottasch">Alan Pottasch</a>, Pepsi's Worldwide Creative Director, at the <a href="/wiki/Shrine_Auditorium" title="Shrine Auditorium">Shrine Auditorium</a> in Los Angeles. During a simulated concert before a full house of fans, pyrotechnics accidentally set Jackson's hair on fire, causing <a href="/wiki/Burn" title="Burn">second-degree burns</a> to his scalp. Jackson underwent treatment to hide the scars and had his third rhinoplasty shortly thereafter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[97]</a></sup> Pepsi settled out of court, and Jackson donated the $1.5<span class="nowrap"> </span>million settlement to the <a href="/wiki/Southern_California_Hospital_at_Culver_City" title="Southern California Hospital at Culver City">Brotman Medical Center</a> in <a href="/wiki/Culver_City,_California" title="Culver City, California">Culver City, California</a>; its now-closed Michael Jackson Burn Center was named in his honor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009279–287_100-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009279–287-100">[98]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[99]</a></sup> Jackson signed a second agreement with Pepsi in the late 1980s for $10<span class="nowrap"> </span>million. The second campaign covered 20 countries and provided financial support for Jackson's <i>Bad</i> album and 1987–88 world tour. Jackson had endorsements and advertising deals with other companies, such as <a href="/wiki/LA_Gear" title="LA Gear">LA Gear</a>, <a href="/wiki/Suzuki" title="Suzuki">Suzuki</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sony" title="Sony">Sony</a>, but none were as significant as his deals with Pepsi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herrera2_97-1"><a href="#cite_note-Herrera2-97">[95]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Victory_Tour_(The_Jacksons_tour)" title="Victory Tour (The Jacksons tour)">Victory Tour</a> of 1984 headlined the Jacksons and showcased Jackson's new solo material to more than two million Americans. It was the last tour he did with his brothers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[100]</a></sup> Following <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Victory_Tour_(The_Jacksons_tour)#Ticket_controversy_and_other_business_issues" title="Victory Tour (The Jacksons tour)">controversy over the concert's ticket sales</a>, Jackson donated his share of the proceeds, an estimated <span class="nowrap">$3 to 5 million</span>, to charity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[101]</a></sup> During the last concert of the Victory Tour at the <a href="/wiki/Dodger_Stadium" title="Dodger Stadium">Dodger Stadium</a> in Los Angeles, Jackson announced his split from The Jacksons during "Shake Your Body".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[102]</a></sup> His charitable work continued with the release of "<a href="/wiki/We_Are_the_World" title="We Are the World">We Are the World</a>" (1985), co-written with <a href="/wiki/Lionel_Richie" title="Lionel Richie">Lionel Richie</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WATW_105-0"><a href="#cite_note-WATW-105">[103]</a></sup> which raised money for the poor in the US and Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jdoyle_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-jdoyle-106">[104]</a></sup> It earned $63<span class="nowrap"> </span>million (equivalent to $158,728,032 in 2021),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jdoyle_106-1"><a href="#cite_note-jdoyle-106">[104]</a></sup> and became one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_singles" title="List of best-selling singles">best-selling singles of all time</a>, with 20<span class="nowrap"> </span>million copies sold.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[105]</a></sup> It won four Grammy Awards in 1985, including Song of the Year for Jackson and Richie as its writers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WATW_105-1"><a href="#cite_note-WATW-105">[103]</a></sup> The project's creators received two special American Music Awards honors: one for the creation of the song and another for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/USA_for_Africa" title="USA for Africa">USA for Africa</a> idea. Jackson, Jones, and promoter Ken Kragen received special awards for their roles in the song's creation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WATW_105-2"><a href="#cite_note-WATW-105">[103]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AMAs_1986_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-AMAs_1986-108">[106]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbell1993114_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell1993114-109">[107]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYoung2009340–344_110-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYoung2009340–344-110">[108]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_autographing_%27We_Are_The_World%27_posters_1985.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1045" data-file-width="704" decoding="async" height="223" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Michael_Jackson_autographing_%27We_Are_The_World%27_posters_1985.jpg/150px-Michael_Jackson_autographing_%27We_Are_The_World%27_posters_1985.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Michael_Jackson_autographing_%27We_Are_The_World%27_posters_1985.jpg/226px-Michael_Jackson_autographing_%27We_Are_The_World%27_posters_1985.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Michael_Jackson_autographing_%27We_Are_The_World%27_posters_1985.jpg/300px-Michael_Jackson_autographing_%27We_Are_The_World%27_posters_1985.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_autographing_%27We_Are_The_World%27_posters_1985.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jackson signing a "<a href="/wiki/We_Are_the_World" title="We Are the World">We Are the World</a>" poster in 1985</div></div></div>
<p>Jackson collaborated with <a href="/wiki/Paul_McCartney" title="Paul McCartney">Paul McCartney</a> in the early 1980s, and learned that McCartney was making $40<span class="nowrap"> </span>million a year from owning the rights to other artists' songs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jdoyle_106-2"><a href="#cite_note-jdoyle-106">[104]</a></sup> By 1983, Jackson had begun buying publishing rights to others' songs, but he was careful with his acquisitions, only bidding on a few of the dozens that were offered to him. Jackson's early acquisitions of <a href="/wiki/Music_catalog" title="Music catalog">music catalogs</a> and song copyrights such as the <a href="/wiki/Sly_Stone" title="Sly Stone">Sly Stone</a> collection included "Everyday People" (1968), <a href="/wiki/Len_Barry" title="Len Barry">Len Barry</a>'s "<a href="/wiki/1-2-3_(Len_Barry_song)" title="1-2-3 (Len Barry song)">1–2–3</a>" (1965), and <a href="/wiki/Dion_DiMucci" title="Dion DiMucci">Dion DiMucci</a>'s "<a href="/wiki/The_Wanderer_(Dion_song)" title="The Wanderer (Dion song)">The Wanderer</a>" (1961) and "<a href="/wiki/Runaround_Sue" title="Runaround Sue">Runaround Sue</a>" (1961).
</p><p>In 1984, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Holmes_%C3%A0_Court" title="Robert Holmes à Court">Robert Holmes à Court</a> announced he was selling the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sony/ATV_Music_Publishing#Acquisition" title="Sony/ATV Music Publishing">ATV Music Publishing</a> catalog comprising the publishing rights to nearly 4,000 songs, including most of the Beatles' material.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hilburn_111-0"><a href="#cite_note-hilburn-111">[109]</a></sup> In 1981, McCartney had been offered the catalog for £20<span class="nowrap"> </span>million ($40<span class="nowrap"> </span>million).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jdoyle_106-3"><a href="#cite_note-jdoyle-106">[104]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mcca_atv_112-0"><a href="#cite_note-mcca_atv-112">[110]</a></sup> Jackson submitted a bid of $46<span class="nowrap"> </span>million on November 20, 1984.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hilburn_111-1"><a href="#cite_note-hilburn-111">[109]</a></sup> When Jackson and McCartney were unable to make a joint purchase, McCartney did not want to be the sole owner of the Beatles' songs, and did not pursue an offer on his own.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009333–338_113-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009333–338-113">[111]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mcca_atv_112-1"><a href="#cite_note-mcca_atv-112">[110]</a></sup> Jackson's agents were unable to come to a deal, and in May 1985 left talks after having spent more than $1<span class="nowrap"> </span>million and four months of <a href="/wiki/Due_diligence" title="Due diligence">due diligence</a> work on the negotiations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hilburn_111-2"><a href="#cite_note-hilburn-111">[109]</a></sup> In June 1985, Jackson and Branca learned that <a href="/wiki/Charles_Koppelman" title="Charles Koppelman">Charles Koppelman</a>'s and <a href="/wiki/Martin_Bandier" title="Martin Bandier">Marty Bandier</a>'s The Entertainment Company had made a tentative offer to buy ATV Music for $50<span class="nowrap"> </span>million; in early August, Holmes à Court contacted Jackson and talks resumed. Jackson's increased bid of $47.5<span class="nowrap"> </span>million (equivalent to $119,675,897 in 2021) was accepted because he could close the deal more quickly, having already completed due diligence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hilburn_111-3"><a href="#cite_note-hilburn-111">[109]</a></sup> Jackson agreed to visit Holmes à Court in Australia, where he would appear on the <a href="/wiki/Channel_Seven_Perth_Telethon" title="Channel Seven Perth Telethon">Channel Seven Perth Telethon</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ch7news_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-ch7news-114">[112]</a></sup> His purchase of ATV Music was finalized on August 10, 1985.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jdoyle_106-4"><a href="#cite_note-jdoyle-106">[104]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hilburn_111-4"><a href="#cite_note-hilburn-111">[109]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Increased_tabloid_speculation_.281986.E2.80.931987.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Increased_tabloid_speculation_(1986–1987)">Increased tabloid speculation (1986–1987)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Health_and_appearance_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Health and appearance of Michael Jackson">Health and appearance of Michael Jackson</a></div>
<p>Jackson's skin had been medium-brown during his youth, but from the mid-1980s gradually grew paler. The change drew widespread media coverage, including speculation that he had been <a href="/wiki/Skin_whitening" title="Skin whitening">bleaching his skin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbell199514–16_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell199514–16-115">[113]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEParameswaran201175–77_116-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEParameswaran201175–77-116">[114]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeMello2012152_117-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeMello2012152-117">[115]</a></sup> His dermatologist, <a href="/wiki/Arnold_Klein" title="Arnold Klein">Arnold Klein</a>, said he observed in 1983 that Jackson had <a href="/wiki/Vitiligo" title="Vitiligo">vitiligo</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rosenberg_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rosenberg-118">[116]</a></sup> a condition characterized by patches of the skin losing their pigment, and sensitivity to sunlight. He also identified <a href="/wiki/Discoid_lupus_erythematosus" title="Discoid lupus erythematosus">discoid lupus erythematosus</a> in Jackson. He diagnosed Jackson with lupus that year,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rosenberg_118-1"><a href="#cite_note-Rosenberg-118">[116]</a></sup> and with vitiligo in 1986.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[117]</a></sup> Vitiligo's drastic effects on the body can cause psychological distress. Jackson used fair-colored makeup,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[118]</a></sup> and possibly skin-bleaching prescription creams,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[119]</a></sup> to cover up the uneven blotches of color caused by the illness. The creams would have further lightened his skin, and, with the application of makeup, he could appear very pale.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009434–436_122-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009434–436-122">[120]</a></sup> Jackson said he had not purposely bleached his skin and could not control his vitiligo, adding, "When people make up stories that I don't want to be who I am, it hurts me."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Oprah-Jackson_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-Oprah-Jackson-123">[121]</a></sup> He became friends with Klein and Klein's assistant, <a href="/wiki/Debbie_Rowe" title="Debbie Rowe">Debbie Rowe</a>. Rowe later became Jackson's second wife and the mother of his first two children.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[122]</a></sup>
</p><p>In his 1988 autobiography and a 1993 interview, Jackson said he had had two <a href="/wiki/Rhinoplasty" title="Rhinoplasty">rhinoplasty</a> surgeries and a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cleft_chin" title="Cleft chin">cleft chin</a> surgery but no more than that. He said he lost weight in the early 1980s because of a change in diet to achieve a dancer's body.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJackson2009229–230_125-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJackson2009229–230-125">[123]</a></sup> Witnesses reported that he was often dizzy, and speculated he was suffering from <a href="/wiki/Anorexia_nervosa" title="Anorexia nervosa">anorexia nervosa</a>. Periods of weight loss became a recurring problem later in his life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009312–313_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009312–313-126">[124]</a></sup> After his death, Jackson's mother said that he first turned to <a href="/wiki/Plastic_surgery#Cosmetic_surgery_procedures" title="Plastic surgery">cosmetic procedures</a> to remedy his vitiligo, because he did not want to look like a "spotted cow". She said he had received more than the two cosmetic surgeries he claimed and speculated that he had become addicted to them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[125]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1986, <a href="/wiki/Tabloid_journalism" title="Tabloid journalism">tabloids</a> reported that Jackson slept in a <a href="/wiki/Hyperbaric_medicine" title="Hyperbaric medicine">hyperbaric oxygen chamber</a> to slow aging, and pictured him lying in a glass box. The claim was untrue, and tabloids reported that he spread the story himself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Image_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-Image-128">[126]</a></sup> They also reported that Jackson took female hormone shots to keep his voice high and facial hair wispy, proposed to <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_Taylor" title="Elizabeth Taylor">Elizabeth Taylor</a> and possibly had a shrine of her, and had cosmetic surgery on his eyes. Jackson's manager <a href="/wiki/Frank_DiLeo" title="Frank DiLeo">Frank DiLeo</a> denied all of them, except for Jackson having a chamber. DiLeo added "I don't know if he sleeps in it. I'm not for it. But Michael thinks it's something that's probably healthy for him. He's a bit of a health fanatic."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[127]</a></sup>
</p><p>When Jackson took his pet chimpanzee <a href="/wiki/Bubbles_(chimpanzee)" title="Bubbles (chimpanzee)">Bubbles</a> to tour in Japan, the media portrayed Jackson as an aspiring <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Disney" title="Disney">Disney</a> cartoon character who befriended animals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[128]</a></sup> It was also reported that Jackson had offered to buy the bones of <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Merrick" title="Joseph Merrick">Joseph Merrick</a> (the "Elephant Man").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009355–361_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009355–361-131">[129]</a></sup> In June 1987, the <i><a href="/wiki/Chicago_Tribune" title="Chicago Tribune">Chicago Tribune</a></i> reported Jackson's publicist bidding $1<span class="nowrap"> </span>million for the skeleton to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_Hospital_Medical_College" title="London Hospital Medical College">London Hospital Medical College</a> on his behalf. The college maintained the skeleton was not for sale. DiLeo said Jackson had an "absorbing interest" in Merrick, "purely based on his awareness of the ethical, medical and historical significance."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[130]</a></sup>
</p><p>These tabloid stories inspired the name "Wacko Jacko", which Jackson came to despise.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_12-1"><a href="#cite_note-allmusic-12">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[131]</a></sup> According to music journalist <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Vogel" title="Joseph Vogel">Joseph Vogel</a>, the demeaning name first appeared in British tabloid <i><a href="/wiki/The_Sun_(United_Kingdom)" title="The Sun (United Kingdom)">The Sun</a></i> in 1985. The name's origins come from <a href="/wiki/Jacco_Macacco" title="Jacco Macacco">Jacko Macacco</a>, the name of a famous monkey used in <a href="/wiki/Monkey-baiting" title="Monkey-baiting">monkey-baiting</a> matches at the Westminster Pit in the early 1820s. "Jacko" was used in <a href="/wiki/Rhyming_slang" title="Rhyming slang">Cockney slang</a> to refer to monkeys in general, hence a racist connotation behind the name.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[132]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jackson worked with <a href="/wiki/George_Lucas" title="George Lucas">George Lucas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Francis_Ford_Coppola" title="Francis Ford Coppola">Francis Ford Coppola</a> on the 17-minute $30<span class="nowrap"> </span>million <a href="/wiki/3D_film" title="3D film">3D film</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Captain_EO" title="Captain EO">Captain EO</a></i>, which ran from 1986 at <a href="/wiki/Disneyland" title="Disneyland">Disneyland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Epcot" title="Epcot">Epcot</a>, and later at <a href="/wiki/Tokyo_Disneyland" title="Tokyo Disneyland">Tokyo Disneyland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Disneyland_Park_(Paris)" title="Disneyland Park (Paris)">Euro Disneyland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[133]</a></sup> After having been removed in the late 1990s, it returned to the theme park for several years after Jackson's death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[134]</a></sup> In 1987, Jackson disassociated himself from the Jehovah's Witnesses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[135]</a></sup> Katherine Jackson said this might have been because some Witnesses strongly opposed the <i>Thriller</i> video.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[136]</a></sup> Michael had denounced it in a Witness publication in 1984.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[137]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Bad.2C_autobiography.2C_and_Neverland_.281987.E2.80.931990.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Bad,_autobiography,_and_Neverland_(1987–1990)"><i>Bad</i>, autobiography, and Neverland (1987–1990)</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:George_H._W._Bush_with_Michael_Jackson.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="917" data-file-width="719" decoding="async" height="217" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/George_H._W._Bush_with_Michael_Jackson.png/170px-George_H._W._Bush_with_Michael_Jackson.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/George_H._W._Bush_with_Michael_Jackson.png/255px-George_H._W._Bush_with_Michael_Jackson.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/George_H._W._Bush_with_Michael_Jackson.png/340px-George_H._W._Bush_with_Michael_Jackson.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:George_H._W._Bush_with_Michael_Jackson.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jackson and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/President_George_H._W._Bush" title="President George H. W. Bush">President George H. W. Bush</a> at the White House on April 5, 1990. It was the second time that Jackson had been honored by a <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">President of the United States</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Jackson's first album in five years, <i><a href="/wiki/Bad_(album)" title="Bad (album)">Bad</a></i> (1987), was highly anticipated, with the industry expecting another major success.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Time2_140-0"><a href="#cite_note-Time2-140">[138]</a></sup> It became the first album to produce five US number-one singles: "<a href="/wiki/I_Just_Can%27t_Stop_Loving_You" title="I Just Can't Stop Loving You">I Just Can't Stop Loving You</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Bad_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Bad (Michael Jackson song)">Bad</a>", "<a href="/wiki/The_Way_You_Make_Me_Feel" title="The Way You Make Me Feel">The Way You Make Me Feel</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Man_in_the_Mirror" title="Man in the Mirror">Man in the Mirror</a>", and "<a href="/wiki/Dirty_Diana" title="Dirty Diana">Dirty Diana</a>". Another song, "<a href="/wiki/Smooth_Criminal" title="Smooth Criminal">Smooth Criminal</a>", peaked at number seven.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FourUSTop10s_61-1"><a href="#cite_note-FourUSTop10s-61">[59]</a></sup> <i>Bad</i> won the 1988 Grammy for Best Engineered Recording – Non Classical and the 1990 <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Music_Video" title="Grammy Award for Best Music Video">Grammy Award for Best Music Video</a>, Short Form for "<a href="/wiki/Leave_Me_Alone_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Leave Me Alone (Michael Jackson song)">Leave Me Alone</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-grammy_mj_65-4"><a href="#cite_note-grammy_mj-65">[63]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bruce_88-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bruce-88">[86]</a></sup> Jackson won an Award of Achievement at the American Music Awards in 1989 after <i>Bad</i> generated five number-one singles, became the first album to top the charts in 25 countries and the best-selling album worldwide in 1987 and 1988.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[139]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[140]</a></sup> By 2012, it had sold between 30 and 45<span class="nowrap"> </span>million copies worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[141]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[142]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Bad_(tour)" title="Bad (tour)">Bad</a> world tour ran from September 12, 1987, to January 14, 1989.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewis_Jones200595–96_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewis_Jones200595–96-145">[143]</a></sup> In Japan, the tour had 14 sellouts and drew 570,000 people, nearly tripling the previous record for a single tour.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[144]</a></sup> The 504,000 people who attended seven sold-out shows at <a href="/wiki/Wembley_Stadium_(1923)" title="Wembley Stadium (1923)">Wembley Stadium</a> set a new <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guinness_World_Record" title="Guinness World Record">Guinness World Record</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[145]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1988, Jackson released his autobiography, <i><a href="/wiki/Moonwalk_(book)" title="Moonwalk (book)">Moonwalk</a></i>, with input from Stephen Davis and <a href="/wiki/Jacqueline_Kennedy_Onassis" title="Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis">Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[146]</a></sup> It sold 200,000 copies,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[147]</a></sup> and reached the top of the <i>New York Times</i> bestsellers list.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[148]</a></sup> Jackson discussed his childhood, the Jackson 5, and the abuse from his father.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJackson200929–31_151-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJackson200929–31-151">[149]</a></sup> He attributed his changing facial appearance to three plastic surgeries, puberty, weight loss, a strict vegetarian diet, a change in hairstyle, and stage lighting.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[150]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJackson2009229–230_125-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJackson2009229–230-125">[123]</a></sup> In June, Jackson was honoured with the Grand Vermeil <a href="/wiki/Medal_of_the_City_of_Paris" title="Medal of the City of Paris">Medal of the City of Paris</a> by the then Mayor of Paris <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Chirac" title="Jacques Chirac">Jacques Chirac</a> during his stay in the city as part of the <a href="/wiki/Bad_(tour)" title="Bad (tour)">Bad</a> world tour.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[151]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[152]</a></sup> In October, Jackson released a film, <i><a href="/wiki/Moonwalker" title="Moonwalker">Moonwalker</a></i>, which featured live footage and short films starring Jackson and <a href="/wiki/Joe_Pesci" title="Joe Pesci">Joe Pesci</a>. In the US it was released <a href="/wiki/Direct-to-video" title="Direct-to-video">direct-to-video</a> and became the best-selling video cassette in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[153]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[154]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Recording_Industry_Association_of_America" title="Recording Industry Association of America">RIAA</a> certified it as eight times Platinum in the US.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[155]</a></sup>
</p><p>In March 1988, Jackson purchased 2,700 acres (11 km<sup>2</sup>) of land near <a href="/wiki/Santa_Ynez,_California" title="Santa Ynez, California">Santa Ynez, California</a>, to build a new home, <a href="/wiki/Neverland_Ranch" title="Neverland Ranch">Neverland Ranch</a>, at a cost of $17<span class="nowrap"> </span>million (equivalent to $38,950,760 in 2021).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Malta_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-Malta-158">[156]</a></sup> He installed a <a href="/wiki/Ferris_wheel" title="Ferris wheel">Ferris wheel</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Carousel" title="Carousel">carousel</a>, a movie theater and a zoo.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Malta_158-1"><a href="#cite_note-Malta-158">[156]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bio2_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bio2-159">[157]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[158]</a></sup> A security staff of 40 patrolled the grounds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bio2_159-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bio2-159">[157]</a></sup> Shortly afterwards, he appeared in the first Western television advertisement in the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[159]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jackson became known as the "<a href="/wiki/Honorific_nicknames_in_popular_music" title="Honorific nicknames in popular music">King of Pop</a>", a nickname that Jackson's publicists embraced.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewis_Jones2005165–168_26-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewis_Jones2005165–168-26">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTETannenbaumMarks2011Chapter_41,_"I_Want_to_Have_a_Nickname"_162-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTETannenbaumMarks2011Chapter_41,_"I_Want_to_Have_a_Nickname"-162'>[160]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ew1991_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-ew1991-163">[161]</a></sup> When <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_Taylor" title="Elizabeth Taylor">Elizabeth Taylor</a> presented him with the Soul Train Heritage Award in 1989, she called him "the true king of pop, rock and soul."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbell1993260–263_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell1993260–263-164">[162]</a></sup> President <a href="/wiki/George_H._W._Bush" title="George H. W. Bush">George H. W. Bush</a> designated him the White House's "Artist of the Decade".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[163]</a></sup> From 1985 to 1990, Jackson donated $455,000 to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Negro_College_Fund" title="United Negro College Fund">United Negro College Fund</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[164]</a></sup> and all profits from his single "Man in the Mirror" went to charity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009382_167-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009382-167">[165]</a></sup> His rendition of "You Were There" at <a href="/wiki/Sammy_Davis_Jr." title="Sammy Davis Jr.">Sammy Davis Jr.</a>'s 60th birthday celebration won Jackson a second Emmy nomination.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-emmys.tv_81-1"><a href="#cite_note-emmys.tv-81">[79]</a></sup> Jackson was the bestselling artist of the 1980s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brooks_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-Brooks-168">[166]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Dangerous_and_public_social_work_.281991.E2.80.931993.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Dangerous_and_public_social_work_(1991–1993)"><i>Dangerous</i> and public social work (1991–1993)</span></h3>
