<p>In March 1991, Jackson renewed his contract with Sony for $65<span class="nowrap"> </span>million (equivalent to $129,317,127 in 2021), a record-breaking deal,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[167]</a></sup> beating <a href="/wiki/Neil_Diamond" title="Neil Diamond">Neil Diamond</a>'s renewal contract with <a href="/wiki/Columbia_Records" title="Columbia Records">Columbia Records</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[168]</a></sup> In 1991, he released his eighth album, <i><a href="/wiki/Dangerous_(Michael_Jackson_album)" title="Dangerous (Michael Jackson album)">Dangerous</a></i>, co-produced with <a href="/wiki/Teddy_Riley" title="Teddy Riley">Teddy Riley</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[169]</a></sup> It was certified eight times platinum in the US, and by 2018 had sold 32<span class="nowrap"> </span>million copies worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Certifications_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-Certifications-172">[170]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[171]</a></sup> In the US, the first single, "<a href="/wiki/Black_or_White" title="Black or White">Black or White</a>", was the album's highest-charting song; it was number one on the <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100 for seven weeks and achieved similar chart performances worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Achievements_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-Achievements-174">[172]</a></sup> The second single, "<a href="/wiki/Remember_the_Time" title="Remember the Time">Remember the Time</a>" peaked at number three on the <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100 singles chart.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-billboard_mj_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-billboard_mj-175">[173]</a></sup> At the end of 1992, <i>Dangerous</i> was the best-selling album of the year worldwide and "Black or White" the best-selling single of the year worldwide at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Billboard_Music_Award" title="Billboard Music Award"><i>Billboard</i> Music Awards</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brooks_168-1"><a href="#cite_note-Brooks-168">[166]</a></sup> In 1993, he performed "Remember the Time" at the <a href="/wiki/Soul_Train_Music_Awards" title="Soul Train Music Awards">Soul Train Music Awards</a> in a chair, saying he twisted his ankle during dance rehearsals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[174]</a></sup> In the UK, "<a href="/wiki/Heal_the_World" title="Heal the World">Heal the World</a>" made No. 2 on the charts in 1992.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OC_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-OC-177">[175]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_Dangerous_World_Tour_1993.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1991" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="264" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Michael_Jackson_Dangerous_World_Tour_1993.jpg/170px-Michael_Jackson_Dangerous_World_Tour_1993.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Michael_Jackson_Dangerous_World_Tour_1993.jpg/255px-Michael_Jackson_Dangerous_World_Tour_1993.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Michael_Jackson_Dangerous_World_Tour_1993.jpg/340px-Michael_Jackson_Dangerous_World_Tour_1993.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_Dangerous_World_Tour_1993.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jackson during the <a href="/wiki/Dangerous_World_Tour" title="Dangerous World Tour">Dangerous World Tour</a> in 1993. <i><a href="/wiki/Dangerous_(Michael_Jackson_album)" title="Dangerous (Michael Jackson album)">Dangerous</a></i> has been recognized by writers as an influence on contemporary pop and R&amp;B artists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[176]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Jackson founded the <a href="/wiki/Heal_the_World_Foundation" title="Heal the World Foundation">Heal the World Foundation</a> in 1992. The charity brought underprivileged children to Jackson's ranch to use the theme park rides, and sent millions of dollars around the globe to help children threatened by war, poverty, and disease. That July, Jackson published his second book, <i><a href="/wiki/Dancing_the_Dream" title="Dancing the Dream">Dancing the Dream</a>,</i> a collection of poetry. The <a href="/wiki/Dangerous_World_Tour" title="Dangerous World Tour">Dangerous World Tour</a> ran between June 1992 and November 1993 and grossed <span class="nowrap">$100 million</span> (equivalent to $187,583,506 in 2021); Jackson performed for 3.5<span class="nowrap"> </span>million people in 70 concerts, all of which were outside the US.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[177]</a></sup> Part of the proceeds went to Heal the World Foundation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[178]</a></sup> Jackson sold the broadcast rights of the tour to <a href="/wiki/HBO" title="HBO">HBO</a> for $20<span class="nowrap"> </span>million, a record-breaking deal that still stands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009452–454_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009452–454-181">[179]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the death of <a href="/wiki/HIV/AIDS" title="HIV/AIDS">HIV/AIDS</a> spokesperson and friend <a href="/wiki/Ryan_White" title="Ryan White">Ryan White</a>, Jackson pleaded with the Clinton administration at <a href="/wiki/First_inauguration_of_Bill_Clinton" title="First inauguration of Bill Clinton">Bill Clinton's inaugural gala</a> to give more money to HIV/AIDS charities and research<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[180]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[181]</a></sup> and performed "<a href="/wiki/Gone_Too_Soon" title="Gone Too Soon">Gone Too Soon</a>", a song dedicated to White, and "Heal the World" at the gala.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[182]</a></sup> Jackson visited Africa in early 1992; on his first stop in Gabon he was greeted by more than 100,000 people, some of them carrying signs that read "Welcome Home Michael",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ebony_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ebony-185">[183]</a></sup> and was awarded an Officer of the <a href="/wiki/National_Order_of_Merit_(Gabon)" title="National Order of Merit (Gabon)">National Order of Merit</a> from President <a href="/wiki/Omar_Bongo" title="Omar Bongo">Omar Bongo</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[184]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[185]</a></sup> During his trip to Ivory Coast, Jackson was crowned "King Sani" by a tribal chief. He thanked the dignitaries in French and English, signed documents formalizing his kingship, and sat on a golden throne while presiding over ceremonial dances.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ebony_185-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ebony-185">[183]</a></sup>
</p><p>In January 1993, Jackson performed at the <a href="/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXVII" title="Super Bowl XXVII">Super Bowl XXVII</a> halftime show in Pasadena, California. The <a href="/wiki/National_Football_League" title="National Football League">NFL</a> sought a big-name artist to keep ratings high during halftime following dwindling audience figures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[186]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[187]</a></sup> It was the first Super Bowl whose half-time performance drew greater audience figures than the game. Jackson played "<a href="/wiki/Jam_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Jam (Michael Jackson song)">Jam</a>", "Billie Jean", "Black or White", and "Heal the World". <i>Dangerous</i> rose 90 places in the US albums chart after the performance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbell199514–16_115-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell199514–16-115">[113]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jackson gave <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson_Talks_..._to_Oprah" title="Michael Jackson Talks ... to Oprah">a 90-minute interview</a> with <a href="/wiki/Oprah_Winfrey" title="Oprah Winfrey">Oprah Winfrey</a> on February 10, 1993. He spoke of his childhood abuse at the hands of his father; he believed he had missed out on much of his childhood, and said that he often cried from loneliness. He denied tabloid rumors that he had bought the bones of the Elephant Man, slept in a hyperbaric oxygen chamber, or bleached his skin, and stated for the first time that he had vitiligo. After the interview, <i>Dangerous</i> re-entered the US albums chart in the top 10, more than a year after its release.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewis_Jones2005165–168_26-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewis_Jones2005165–168-26">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbell199514–16_115-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell199514–16-115">[113]</a></sup>
</p><p>In January 1993, Jackson won three <a href="/wiki/American_Music_Awards" title="American Music Awards">American Music Awards</a>: Favorite Pop/Rock Album (<i>Dangerous</i>), Favorite Soul/R&amp;B Single ("Remember the Time"), and was the first to win the International Artist Award of Excellence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[188]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[189]</a></sup> In February, he won the "Living Legend Award" at the <a href="/wiki/35th_Annual_Grammy_Awards" title="35th Annual Grammy Awards">35th Annual Grammy Awards</a> in Los Angeles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-grammy_mj_65-5"><a href="#cite_note-grammy_mj-65">[63]</a></sup> He attended the award ceremony with <a href="/wiki/Brooke_Shields" title="Brooke Shields">Brooke Shields</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[190]</a></sup> <i>Dangerous</i> was nominated for Best Vocal Performance (for "Black or White"), Best R&amp;B Vocal Performance ("Jam") and Best R&amp;B Song ("Jam"), and Bruce Swedien and Teddy Riley won the Grammy for Best Engineered – Non Classical.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bruce_88-2"><a href="#cite_note-Bruce-88">[86]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="First_child_sexual_abuse_accusations_and_first_marriage_.281993.E2.80.931995.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="First_child_sexual_abuse_accusations_and_first_marriage_(1993–1995)">First child sexual abuse accusations and first marriage (1993–1995)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/1993_child_sexual_abuse_accusations_against_Michael_Jackson" title="1993 child sexual abuse accusations against Michael Jackson">1993 child sexual abuse accusations against Michael Jackson</a></div>
<p>In August 1993, Jackson was accused of <a href="/wiki/Child_sexual_abuse" title="Child sexual abuse">child sexual abuse</a> by a 13-year-old boy, Jordan Chandler, and his father, Evan Chandler.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Abuse_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-Abuse-193">[191]</a></sup> Jordan said he and Jackson had engaged in acts of kissing, <a href="/wiki/Masturbation" title="Masturbation">masturbation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oral_sex" title="Oral sex">oral sex</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009496–498_194-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009496–498-194">[192]</a></sup> While Jordan's mother initially told police that she did not believe Jackson had molested him, her position wavered a few days later.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[193]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009477–478_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009477–478-196">[194]</a></sup> Evan was recorded discussing his intention to pursue charges, which Jackson used to argue that he was the victim of a jealous father trying to extort money.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009477–478_196-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009477–478-196">[194]</a></sup> Jackson's older sister La Toya accused him of being a pedophile;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009534–540_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009534–540-197">[195]</a></sup> she later retracted this, saying she had been forced into it by her abusive husband.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbell199528–29_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell199528–29-198">[196]</a></sup> Police raided Jackson's home in August and found two legal large-format art books featuring young boys playing, running and swimming in various states of undress.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[197]</a></sup> Jackson denied knowing of the books' content and claimed if they were there someone had to send them to him and he did not open them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[198]</a></sup> Jordan Chandler gave police a description of Jackson's genitals. A strip search was made, and the jurors felt the description was not a match.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[199]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[200]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[201]</a></sup> In January 1994, Jackson settled with the Chandlers out of court for a reported total sum of $23 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[202]</a></sup> The police never pressed criminal charges.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[203]</a></sup> Citing a lack of evidence without Jordan's testimony, the state closed its investigation on September 22, 1994.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[204]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jackson had been taking <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Painkiller" title="Painkiller">painkillers</a> for his reconstructive scalp surgeries, administered due to the Pepsi commercial accident in 1984, and became dependent on them to cope with the stress of the sexual abuse allegations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[205]</a></sup> On November 12, 1993, Jackson canceled the remainder of the Dangerous Tour due to health problems, stress from the allegations and painkiller addiction. He thanked close friend <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_Taylor" title="Elizabeth Taylor">Elizabeth Taylor</a> for support, encouragement and counsel. The end of the tour concluded his relationship with Pepsi Cola, which sponsored the tour.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[206]</a></sup>
</p><p>In late 1993, Jackson proposed to <a href="/wiki/Lisa_Marie_Presley" title="Lisa Marie Presley">Lisa Marie Presley</a>, daughter of Elvis Presley, over the phone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009518–520_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009518–520-209">[207]</a></sup> They married in <a href="/wiki/La_Vega,_Dominican_Republic" title="La Vega, Dominican Republic">La Vega, Dominican Republic</a>, in May 1994 by civil judge Hugo Francisco Álvarez Pérez.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wed_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wed-210">[208]</a></sup> The tabloid media speculated that the wedding was a publicity stunt to deflect Jackson's sexual abuse allegations and jump-start Presley's career as a singer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Divorce_211-0"><a href="#cite_note-Divorce-211">[209]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wed_210-1"><a href="#cite_note-Wed-210">[208]</a></sup> Their marriage ended little more than a year later, and they separated in December 1995.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009580–581_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009580–581-212">[210]</a></sup> Presley cited "irreconcilable differences" when filing for divorce the next month and only sought to reclaim her maiden name as her settlement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Divorce_211-1"><a href="#cite_note-Divorce-211">[209]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[211]</a></sup> After the divorce, Judge Pérez said, "They lasted longer than I thought they would. I gave them a year. They lasted a year and a half."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wed_210-2"><a href="#cite_note-Wed-210">[208]</a></sup> In an October 2010 interview with talk-show host Oprah Winfrey, Presley revealed that she and Jackson had attempted to reconcile intermittently for four years following their divorce, and that she had travelled to different parts of the world in order to be with him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[212]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jackson was set to compose music for the <a href="/wiki/Sega_Genesis" title="Sega Genesis">Sega Genesis</a> video game <i><a href="/wiki/Sonic_the_Hedgehog_3" title="Sonic the Hedgehog 3">Sonic the Hedgehog 3</a></i> (1994), but left the project around the time the sexual abuse allegations surfaced and went uncredited. Jackson was a <i><a href="/wiki/Sonic_the_Hedgehog" title="Sonic the Hedgehog">Sonic the Hedgehog</a></i> fan,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-untoldvol3_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-untoldvol3-215">[213]</a></sup> and had collaborated with <a href="/wiki/Sega" title="Sega">Sega</a> for the 1990 arcade game <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Moonwalker_(video_game)" title="Moonwalker (video game)">Moonwalker</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[214]</a></sup> The reasons for Jackson's departure and whether his compositions remain in the released game have been the subject of debate. <a href="/wiki/Sega_Technical_Institute" title="Sega Technical Institute">Sega Technical Institute</a> director Roger Hector and <i>Sonic the Hedgehog</i> co-creator <a href="/wiki/Naoto_Ohshima" title="Naoto Ohshima">Naoto Ohshima</a> said that Jackson's involvement was terminated and his music reworked following the allegations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-untoldvol3_215-1"><a href="#cite_note-untoldvol3-215">[213]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[215]</a></sup> However, Jackson's musical director <a href="/wiki/Brad_Buxer" title="Brad Buxer">Brad Buxer</a> and two other members of Jackson's team, Doug Grigsby III and Ciorocco Jones, said the music remained and that Jackson went uncredited because he was unhappy with how the Genesis replicated his music.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[216]</a></sup> <i>Sonic 3</i> producer <a href="/wiki/Yuji_Naka" title="Yuji Naka">Yuji Naka</a> would later confirm in 2022 that Jackson had indeed composed some of the songs in the game and that the development team had visited his home, while expressing disappointment that his songs were replaced in the compilation game <i><a href="/wiki/Sonic_Origins" title="Sonic Origins">Sonic Origins</a></i> (2022) allegedly due to a royalty dispute with Jackson's estate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[217]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="HIStory.2C_second_marriage.2C_and_fatherhood_.281995.E2.80.931997.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="HIStory,_second_marriage,_and_fatherhood_(1995–1997)"><i>HIStory</i>, second marriage, and fatherhood (1995–1997)</span></h3>
<p>In June 1995, Jackson released the double album <i><a href="/wiki/HIStory:_Past,_Present_and_Future,_Book_I" title="HIStory: Past, Present and Future, Book I">HIStory: Past, Present and Future, Book I</a></i>. The first disc, <i>HIStory Begins</i>, is a <a href="/wiki/Greatest_hits_album" title="Greatest hits album">greatest hits album</a> (reissued in 2001 as <i>Greatest Hits: HIStory, Volume I</i>). The second disc, <i>HIStory Continues</i>, contains 13 original songs and two cover versions. The album debuted at number one on the charts and has been certified for eight million shipments in the US.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[218]</a></sup> It is the best-selling multi-disc album of all time, with 20<span class="nowrap"> </span>million copies (40<span class="nowrap"> </span>million units) sold worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Achievements_174-1"><a href="#cite_note-Achievements-174">[172]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[219]</a></sup> <i>HIStory</i> received a Grammy nomination for <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Album_of_the_Year" title="Grammy Award for Album of the Year">Album of the Year</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-grammy_mj_65-6"><a href="#cite_note-grammy_mj-65">[63]</a></sup> The <i>New York Times</i> reviewed it as "the testimony of a musician whose self-pity now equals his talent".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[220]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first single from <i>HIStory</i> was "<a href="/wiki/Scream_(Michael_Jackson_and_Janet_Jackson_song)" title="Scream (Michael Jackson and Janet Jackson song)">Scream</a>/<a href="/wiki/Childhood_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Childhood (Michael Jackson song)">Childhood</a>". "Scream", a duet with Jackson's youngest sister Janet, protests the media's treatment of Jackson during the 1993 child abuse allegations against him. The single reached number five on the <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-billboard_mj_175-1"><a href="#cite_note-billboard_mj-175">[173]</a></sup> and received a Grammy nomination for "Best Pop Collaboration with Vocals".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-grammy_mj_65-7"><a href="#cite_note-grammy_mj-65">[63]</a></sup> The second single, "<a href="/wiki/You_Are_Not_Alone" title="You Are Not Alone">You Are Not Alone</a>", holds the Guinness world record for the first song to debut at number one on the <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100 chart.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-World_Records_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-World_Records-223">[221]</a></sup> It received a Grammy nomination for "Best Pop Vocal Performance" in 1995.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-grammy_mj_65-8"><a href="#cite_note-grammy_mj-65">[63]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1995 the <a href="/wiki/Anti-Defamation_League" title="Anti-Defamation League">Anti-Defamation League</a> and other groups complained that "Jew me, sue me, everybody do me/ Kick me, <a href="/wiki/Kike" title="Kike">kike</a> me, don't you black or white me", the original lyrics of "<a href="/wiki/They_Don%27t_Care_About_Us" title="They Don't Care About Us">They Don't Care About Us</a>", were <a href="/wiki/Antisemitism_in_the_United_States" title="Antisemitism in the United States">antisemitic</a>. Jackson released a version with revised words.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[222]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ADL_225-0"><a href="#cite_note-ADL-225">[223]</a></sup>
</p><p>
In late 1995, Jackson was admitted to a hospital after collapsing during rehearsals for a televised performance, caused by a stress-related <a href="/wiki/Panic_attack" title="Panic attack">panic attack</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009576–577_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009576–577-226">[224]</a></sup> In November, Jackson merged his ATV Music catalog with Sony's music publishing division, creating <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sony/ATV_Music_Publishing" title="Sony/ATV Music Publishing">Sony/ATV Music Publishing</a>. He retained ownership of half the company, earning $95<span class="nowrap"> </span>million up front (equivalent to $168,941,909 in 2021) as well as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Sony/ATV_Music_Publishing_artists" title="List of Sony/ATV Music Publishing artists">rights to more songs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[225]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sonydeal_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-sonydeal-228">[226]</a></sup></p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_Cannescropped.jpg"><img alt="Close-up of a pale skinned Jackson with black hair. He is wearing a black jacket with white designs on it." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="567" data-file-width="417" decoding="async" height="231" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Michael_Jackson_Cannescropped.jpg/170px-Michael_Jackson_Cannescropped.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Michael_Jackson_Cannescropped.jpg/255px-Michael_Jackson_Cannescropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Michael_Jackson_Cannescropped.jpg/340px-Michael_Jackson_Cannescropped.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_Cannescropped.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jackson at the <a href="/wiki/1997_Cannes_Film_Festival" title="1997 Cannes Film Festival">1997 Cannes Film Festival</a> for the premiere of <i><a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson%27s_Ghosts" title="Michael Jackson's Ghosts">Michael Jackson's Ghosts</a></i></div></div></div>
<p>"<a href="/wiki/Earth_Song" title="Earth Song">Earth Song</a>" was the third single released from <i>HIStory</i>, and topped the <a href="/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart" title="UK Singles Chart">UK Singles Chart</a> for six weeks over Christmas 1995.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OC_177-1"><a href="#cite_note-OC-177">[175]</a></sup> It became the 87th-bestselling single in the UK.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[227]</a></sup> At the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1996_Brit_Awards" title="1996 Brit Awards">1996 Brit Awards</a>, Jackson's performance of "Earth Song" was disrupted by <a href="/wiki/Pulp_(band)" title="Pulp (band)">Pulp</a> singer <a href="/wiki/Jarvis_Cocker" title="Jarvis Cocker">Jarvis Cocker</a>, who was protesting what Cocker saw as Jackson's "Christ-like" persona. Jackson said the stage invasion was "disgusting and cowardly".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[228]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[229]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1996, Jackson won a Grammy for Best Music Video, Short Form, for "Scream" and an American Music Award for Favorite Pop/Rock Male Artist.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-grammy_mj_65-9"><a href="#cite_note-grammy_mj-65">[63]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[230]</a></sup> Jackson promoted <i>HIStory</i> with the <a href="/wiki/HIStory_World_Tour" title="HIStory World Tour">HIStory World Tour</a>, from September 7, 1996, to October 15, 1997. He performed 82 concerts in five continents, 35 countries and 58 cities to over 4.5<span class="nowrap"> </span>million fans, his most attended tour. It grossed <span class="nowrap">$165 million</span>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewis_Jones200595–96_145-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewis_Jones200595–96-145">[143]</a></sup> During the tour, in Sydney, Australia, Jackson married <a href="/wiki/Debbie_Rowe" title="Debbie Rowe">Debbie Rowe</a>, a dermatology assistant, who was six months pregnant with his first child.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009570–586_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009570–586-233">[231]</a></sup> Michael Joseph Jackson Jr. (commonly known as Prince) was born on February 13, 1997; his sister <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paris_Jackson_(actress)" title="Paris Jackson (actress)">Paris-Michael Katherine Jackson</a> was born a year later on April 3, 1998.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009580–581,_597_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009580–581,_597-234">[232]</a></sup> Jackson and Rowe divorced in 2000, and Rowe conceded custody of the children, with an $8<span class="nowrap"> </span>million settlement (equivalent to $14,639,832 in 2021).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[233]</a></sup>. In 2004, after the <a href="/wiki/Trial_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Trial of Michael Jackson">second child abuse allegations against Jackson</a>, she returned to court to reclaim custody. The suit was settled in 2006.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ex_wife_236-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ex_wife-236">[234]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1997, Jackson released <i><a href="/wiki/Blood_on_the_Dance_Floor:_HIStory_in_the_Mix" title="Blood on the Dance Floor: HIStory in the Mix">Blood on the Dance Floor: HIStory in the Mix</a></i>, which contained remixes of singles from <i>HIStory</i> and five new songs. Worldwide sales stand at <span class="nowrap">6 million</span> copies, making it the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_remix_albums" title="List of best-selling remix albums">best-selling remix album of all time</a>. It reached number one in the UK, as did the <a href="/wiki/Blood_on_the_Dance_Floor_(song)" title="Blood on the Dance Floor (song)">title track</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERojek200774_237-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERojek200774-237">[235]</a></sup> In the US, the album reached number 24 and was certified platinum.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Certifications_172-1"><a href="#cite_note-Certifications-172">[170]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Label_dispute_and_Invincible_.281997.E2.80.932002.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Label_dispute_and_Invincible_(1997–2002)">Label dispute and <i>Invincible</i> (1997–2002)</span></h3>
<p>From October 1997 to September 2001, Jackson worked on his tenth solo album, <i><a href="/wiki/Invincible_(Michael_Jackson_album)" title="Invincible (Michael Jackson album)">Invincible</a></i>, which cost <span class="nowrap">$30 million</span> to record.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Burkeman_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-Burkeman-238">[236]</a></sup> In June 1999, Jackson joined <a href="/wiki/Luciano_Pavarotti" title="Luciano Pavarotti">Luciano Pavarotti</a> for a <a href="/wiki/War_Child_(charity)" title="War Child (charity)">War Child</a> benefit concert in Modena, Italy. The show raised a million dollars for refugees of the <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_War" title="Kosovo War">Kosovo War</a>, and additional funds for the children of Guatemala.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[237]</a></sup> Later that month, Jackson organized a series of "<a href="/wiki/MJ_%26_Friends" title="MJ &amp; Friends">Michael Jackson &amp; Friends</a>" benefit concerts in Germany and Korea. Other artists involved included <a href="/wiki/Slash_(musician)" title="Slash (musician)">Slash</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scorpions_(band)" title="Scorpions (band)">The Scorpions</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boyz_II_Men" title="Boyz II Men">Boyz II Men</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luther_Vandross" title="Luther Vandross">Luther Vandross</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mariah_Carey" title="Mariah Carey">Mariah Carey</a>, <a href="/wiki/A._R._Rahman" title="A. R. Rahman">A. R. Rahman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prabhu_Deva" title="Prabhu Deva">Prabhu Deva</a> Sundaram, <a href="/wiki/Shobana" title="Shobana">Shobana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andrea_Bocelli" title="Andrea Bocelli">Andrea Bocelli</a>, and Luciano Pavarotti. The proceeds went to the <a href="/wiki/Nelson_Mandela_Children%27s_Fund" title="Nelson Mandela Children's Fund">Nelson Mandela Children's Fund</a>, the <a href="/wiki/International_Red_Cross_and_Red_Crescent_Movement" title="International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement">Red Cross</a> and <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[238]</a></sup> From August 1999 to 2000, he lived in New York City at 4 <a href="/wiki/74th_Street_(Manhattan)" title="74th Street (Manhattan)">East 74th Street</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[239]</a></sup> At the turn of the century, Jackson won an American Music Award as Artist of the 1980s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MTV_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-MTV-242">[240]</a></sup> In 2000, <i>Guinness World Records</i> recognized him for supporting 39 charities, more than any other entertainer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[241]</a></sup>
</p><p>In September 2001, two <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson:_30th_Anniversary_Special" title="Michael Jackson: 30th Anniversary Special">30th Anniversary concerts</a> were held at Madison Square Garden to mark Jackson's 30th year as a solo artist. Jackson performed with his brothers for the first time since 1984. The show also featured <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/M%C3%BDa" title="Mýa">Mýa</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Usher_(singer)" title="Usher (singer)">Usher</a>, <a href="/wiki/Whitney_Houston" title="Whitney Houston">Whitney Houston</a>, <a href="/wiki/Destiny%27s_Child" title="Destiny's Child">Destiny's Child</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monica_(singer)" title="Monica (singer)">Monica</a>, <a href="/wiki/Liza_Minnelli" title="Liza Minnelli">Liza Minnelli</a>, and Slash. The first show was marred by technical lapses, and the crowd booed a speech by <a href="/wiki/Marlon_Brando" title="Marlon Brando">Marlon Brando</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[242]</a></sup> Almost 30<span class="nowrap"> </span>million people watched the television broadcast of the shows in November.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[243]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">September 11 attacks</a>, Jackson helped organize the <a href="/wiki/United_We_Stand:_What_More_Can_I_Give" title="United We Stand: What More Can I Give">United We Stand: What More Can I Give</a> benefit concert at <a href="/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy_Memorial_Stadium" title="Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium">RFK Stadium</a> in Washington, D.C. on October 21, 2001. Jackson performed "<a href="/wiki/What_More_Can_I_Give" title="What More Can I Give">What More Can I Give</a>" as the finale.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009614–617_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009614–617-246">[244]</a></sup>
</p><p>The release of <i>Invincible</i> was preceded by a dispute between Jackson and his record label, Sony Music Entertainment. Jackson had expected the licenses to the masters of his albums to revert to him in the early 2000s, after which he would be able to promote the material however he pleased and keep the profits, but clauses in the contract set the revert date years into the future. Jackson sought an early exit from his contract.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009610–611_247-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009610–611-247">[245]</a></sup> <i>Invincible</i> was released on October 30, 2001. It was Jackson's first full-length album in six years, and the last album of original material he released in his lifetime.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009610–611_247-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009610–611-247">[245]</a></sup> It debuted at number one in 13 countries and went on to sell eight<span class="nowrap"> </span>million copies worldwide, receiving double-platinum certification in the US.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Certifications_172-2"><a href="#cite_note-Certifications-172">[170]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[246]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[247]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2003_Michael_Jackson_at_The_Cable_Show_(29358712934)_(1).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="783" decoding="async" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/2003_Michael_Jackson_at_The_Cable_Show_%2829358712934%29_%281%29.jpg/200px-2003_Michael_Jackson_at_The_Cable_Show_%2829358712934%29_%281%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/2003_Michael_Jackson_at_The_Cable_Show_%2829358712934%29_%281%29.jpg/300px-2003_Michael_Jackson_at_The_Cable_Show_%2829358712934%29_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/2003_Michael_Jackson_at_The_Cable_Show_%2829358712934%29_%281%29.jpg/400px-2003_Michael_Jackson_at_The_Cable_Show_%2829358712934%29_%281%29.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2003_Michael_Jackson_at_The_Cable_Show_(29358712934)_(1).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jackson in 2003</div></div></div>
<p>On January 9, 2002, Jackson won his 22nd American Music Award for Artist of the Century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[248]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[249]</a></sup> <span class="anchor" id="PrinceII"></span>Later that year, an anonymous <a href="/wiki/Surrogacy" title="Surrogacy">surrogate mother</a> gave birth to his third child, Prince Michael Jackson II (nicknamed "Blanket"), who had been conceived by <a href="/wiki/Artificial_insemination" title="Artificial insemination">artificial insemination</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009599–600_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009599–600-252">[250]</a></sup> On November 20, Jackson briefly held Blanket over the railing of his Berlin hotel room, four stories above ground level, prompting widespread criticism in the media. Jackson apologized for the incident, calling it "a terrible mistake".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vineyard_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-Vineyard-253">[251]</a></sup> On January 22, promoter Marcel Avram filed a breach of contract complaint against Jackson for failing to perform two planned 1999 concerts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[252]</a></sup> In March, a Santa Maria jury ordered Jackson to pay Avram $5.3<span class="nowrap"> </span>million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[253]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[254]</a></sup> On December 18, 2003, Jackson's attorneys dropped all appeals on the verdict and settled the lawsuit for an undisclosed amount.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[255]</a></sup>
</p><p>On April 24, 2002, Jackson performed at <a href="/wiki/Apollo_Theater" title="Apollo Theater">Apollo Theater</a>. The concert was a fundraiser for the Democratic National Committee and former President Bill Clinton.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[256]</a></sup> The money collected would be used to encourage citizens to vote. It raised $2.5<span class="nowrap"> </span>million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[257]</a></sup> The concert was called <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson:_Live_at_the_Apollo_2002" title="Michael Jackson: Live at the Apollo 2002">Michael Jackson: Live at the Apollo</a> and was one of Jackson's final on-stage performances.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[258]</a></sup>
</p><p>In July 2002, Jackson called Sony Music chairman <a href="/wiki/Tommy_Mottola" title="Tommy Mottola">Tommy Mottola</a> "a racist, and very, very, very devilish," and someone who exploits black artists for his own gain, at <a href="/wiki/Al_Sharpton" title="Al Sharpton">Al Sharpton's</a> <a href="/wiki/National_Action_Network" title="National Action Network">National Action Network</a> in Harlem. The accusation prompted Sharpton to form a coalition investigating whether Mottola exploited black artists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mottola_261-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mottola-261">[259]</a></sup> Jackson charged that Mottola had called his colleague <a href="/wiki/Irv_Gotti" title="Irv Gotti">Irv Gotti</a> a "fat <a href="/wiki/Nigger" title="Nigger">nigger</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[260]</a></sup> Responding to those attacks, Sony issued a statement calling them "ludicrous, spiteful, and hurtful" and defended Mottola as someone who had championed Jackson's career for many years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mottola_261-1"><a href="#cite_note-Mottola-261">[259]</a></sup> Sony ultimately refused to renew Jackson's contract and claimed that a <span class="nowrap">$25 million</span> promotional campaign had failed because Jackson refused to tour in the US for <i>Invincible</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Burkeman_238-1"><a href="#cite_note-Burkeman-238">[236]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Second_child_abuse_allegations_and_acquittal_.282002.E2.80.932005.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Second_child_abuse_allegations_and_acquittal_(2002–2005)">Second child abuse allegations and acquittal (2002–2005)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Living_with_Michael_Jackson" title="Living with Michael Jackson">Living with Michael Jackson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Trial_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Trial of Michael Jackson">Trial of Michael Jackson</a>, and <a href="/wiki/FBI_files_on_Michael_Jackson" title="FBI files on Michael Jackson">FBI files on Michael Jackson</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michaeljacksonmug1_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="340" data-file-width="253" decoding="async" height="296" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Michaeljacksonmug1_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Michaeljacksonmug1_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/32/Michaeljacksonmug1_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michaeljacksonmug1_(cropped).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jackson's <a href="/wiki/Mug_shot" title="Mug shot">mug shot</a>, taken on November 20, 2003</div></div></div>
<p>Beginning in May 2002, a documentary film crew led by <a href="/wiki/Martin_Bashir" title="Martin Bashir">Martin Bashir</a> followed Jackson for several months.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vineyard_253-1"><a href="#cite_note-Vineyard-253">[251]</a></sup> The documentary, broadcast in February 2003 as <i><a href="/wiki/Living_with_Michael_Jackson" title="Living with Michael Jackson">Living with Michael Jackson</a></i>, showed Jackson holding hands and discussing sleeping arrangements with a 12-year-old boy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbcnews_25-1"><a href="#cite_note-bbcnews-25">[23]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009640_263-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009640-263">[261]</a></sup> He said that he saw nothing wrong with having sleepovers with minors and sharing his bed and bedroom with various people, which aroused controversy. He insisted that the sleepovers were not sexual and that his words had been misunderstood.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[262]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[263]</a></sup>
</p><p>In October 2003, Jackson received the <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_City#Key_to_the_City" title="Freedom of the City">Key to the City</a> of <a href="/wiki/Las_Vegas" title="Las Vegas">Las Vegas</a> from Mayor <a href="/wiki/Oscar_Goodman" title="Oscar Goodman">Oscar Goodman</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[264]</a></sup> On November 18, 2003, Sony released <i><a href="/wiki/Number_Ones_(Michael_Jackson_album)" title="Number Ones (Michael Jackson album)">Number Ones</a></i>, a <a href="/wiki/Number_Ones_(Michael_Jackson_album)" title="Number Ones (Michael Jackson album)">greatest hits compilation</a>. It was certified five-times platinum by the RIAA, and nine times platinum in the UK, for shipments of at least 2.7<span class="nowrap"> </span>million units.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Certifications_172-3"><a href="#cite_note-Certifications-172">[170]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[265]</a></sup>
</p><p>On December 18, 2003, Santa Barbara authorities charged Jackson with seven counts of child molestation and two counts of intoxicating a minor with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alcoholic_drink" title="Alcoholic drink">alcoholic drinks</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[266]</a></sup> Jackson denied the allegations and pleaded not guilty.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[267]</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Trial_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Trial of Michael Jackson">People v. Jackson</a></i> trial began on January 31, 2005, in <a href="/wiki/Santa_Maria,_California" title="Santa Maria, California">Santa Maria, California</a>, and lasted until the end of May. Jackson found the experience stressful and it affected his health. If convicted, he would have faced up to 20 years in prison.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_health_270-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_health-270">[268]</a></sup> On June 13, 2005, Jackson was acquitted on all counts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[269]</a></sup> After the trial, he became reclusive<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-indie-auction_272-0"><a href="#cite_note-indie-auction-272">[270]</a></sup> and moved to <a href="/wiki/Bahrain" title="Bahrain">Bahrain</a> as a guest of <a href="/wiki/Abdullah_bin_Hamad_bin_Isa_Al_Khalifa" title="Abdullah bin Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa">Sheikh Abdullah</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[271]</a></sup>
In December 2009, The <a href="/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation" title="Federal Bureau of Investigation">Federal Bureau of Investigation</a> (FBI) released files on Michael Jackson. These files revealed the Bureau's role in the 2005 trial and the 1993 allegations against Jackson, among other revelations. The FBI found no evidence of criminal conduct on Jackson's behalf.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[272]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[273]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Final_years_and_This_Is_It_.282006.E2.80.932009.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Final_years_and_This_Is_It_(2006–2009)">Final years and <i>This Is It</i> (2006–2009)</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_and_son_Blanket_(169436395).jpg"><img alt="Jackson is wearing an overcoat and walking from left to right. His face is obscured by his hair. His son is wearing a mask and a baseball cap. Two men are with them; a third person is holding an umbrella over the Jacksons." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1128" data-file-width="765" decoding="async" height="251" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Michael_Jackson_and_son_Blanket_%28169436395%29.jpg/170px-Michael_Jackson_and_son_Blanket_%28169436395%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Michael_Jackson_and_son_Blanket_%28169436395%29.jpg/255px-Michael_Jackson_and_son_Blanket_%28169436395%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Michael_Jackson_and_son_Blanket_%28169436395%29.jpg/340px-Michael_Jackson_and_son_Blanket_%28169436395%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_and_son_Blanket_(169436395).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jackson and his son Blanket in <a href="/wiki/Disneyland_Paris" title="Disneyland Paris">Disneyland Paris</a>, 2006</div></div></div>
<p>In April 2006, Jackson agreed to use a piece of his ATV catalog stake, then worth about $1<span class="nowrap"> </span>billion, as <a href="/wiki/Collateral_(finance)" title="Collateral (finance)">collateral</a> against his $270<span class="nowrap"> </span>million worth of loans from <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_America" title="Bank of America">Bank of America</a>. Bank of America had sold the loans to <a href="/wiki/Fortress_Investment_Group" title="Fortress Investment Group">Fortress Investments</a>, an investment company that buys distressed loans, the year before. As part of the agreement, Fortress Investments provided Jackson a new loan of $300<span class="nowrap"> </span>million with reduced interest payments (equivalent to $403,251,898 in 2021). Sony Music would have the option to buy half of his stake, or about 25% of the catalog, at a set price. Jackson's financial managers had urged him to shed part of his stake to avoid bankruptcy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sonydeal_228-1"><a href="#cite_note-sonydeal-228">[226]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[274]</a></sup> The main house at Neverland Ranch was closed as a cost-cutting measure, while Jackson lived in Bahrain at the hospitality of Sheik Abdullah, the ruler's son.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[275]</a></sup> At least 30 of Jackson's employees had not been paid on time and were owed $306,000 in back wages; Jackson was ordered to pay $100,000 in penalties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sonydeal_228-2"><a href="#cite_note-sonydeal-228">[226]</a></sup>
</p><p>In early 2006, it was announced that Jackson had signed a contract with a Bahrain-based startup, Two Seas Records; nothing came of the deal, and Two Seas CEO <a href="/wiki/Gut_Records" title="Gut Records">Guy Holmes</a> later said it was never finalized.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[276]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bahrain_279-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bahrain-279">[277]</a></sup> That October, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fox_News_Channel" title="Fox News Channel">Fox News</a> reported that Jackson had been recording at a studio in <a href="/wiki/County_Westmeath" title="County Westmeath">County Westmeath</a>, Ireland. It was not known what Jackson was working on, or who had paid for the sessions; his publicist stated that he had left Two Seas by then.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bahrain_279-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bahrain-279">[277]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[278]</a></sup>
</p><p>In November 2006, Jackson invited an <i><a href="/wiki/Access_Hollywood" title="Access Hollywood">Access Hollywood</a></i> camera crew into the studio in Westmeath, and <a href="/wiki/MSNBC" title="MSNBC">MSNBC</a> reported that he was working on a new album, produced by <a href="/wiki/Will.i.am" title="Will.i.am">will.i.am</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Achievements_174-2"><a href="#cite_note-Achievements-174">[172]</a></sup> On November 15, Jackson briefly performed "We Are the World" at the <a href="/wiki/2006_World_Music_Awards" title="2006 World Music Awards">World Music Awards</a> in London and accepted the Diamond Award honoring the sale of over <span class="nowrap">100 million</span> records. The event was Jackson's last public performance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Achievements_174-3"><a href="#cite_note-Achievements-174">[172]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[279]</a></sup> He returned to the U.S. in December 2006, settling in <a href="/wiki/Las_Vegas" title="Las Vegas">Las Vegas</a>, and attended <a href="/wiki/James_Brown" title="James Brown">James Brown</a>'s funeral in <a href="/wiki/Augusta,_Georgia" title="Augusta, Georgia">Augusta, Georgia</a> later that month, where he gave a eulogy calling Brown his greatest inspiration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[280]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2007, Jackson and Sony bought another music publishing company, <a href="/wiki/Famous_Music" title="Famous Music">Famous Music</a> LLC, formerly owned by <a href="/wiki/Viacom_(2005%E2%80%932019)" title="Viacom (2005–2019)">Viacom</a>. The deal gave him the rights to songs by <a href="/wiki/Eminem" title="Eminem">Eminem</a> and <a href="/wiki/Beck" title="Beck">Beck</a>, among others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[281]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[282]</a></sup> In a brief interview with the <a href="/wiki/Associated_Press" title="Associated Press">Associated Press</a> in Tokyo, Jackson said he had no regrets about his lifelong career despite difficulties and "deliberate attempts to hurt [him]".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[283]</a></sup> That March, Jackson visited a US Army post in Japan, <a href="/wiki/Camp_Zama" title="Camp Zama">Camp Zama</a>, to greet over 3,000 troops and their families.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[284]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[285]</a></sup>
</p><p>In September 2007, Jackson was still working on his next album, which he never completed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[286]</a></sup> For the 25th anniversary of <i>Thriller</i> in 2008, Jackson and Sony released <i><a href="/wiki/Thriller_25" title="Thriller 25">Thriller 25</a></i>, with two remixes released as singles: "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Girl_Is_Mine_2008" title="The Girl Is Mine 2008">The Girl Is Mine 2008</a>" and "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wanna_Be_Startin%27_Somethin%27_2008" title="Wanna Be Startin' Somethin' 2008">Wanna Be Startin' Somethin' 2008</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[287]</a></sup> For Jackson's 50th birthday, Sony BMG released a series of greatest hits albums, <i><a href="/wiki/King_of_Pop_(album)" title="King of Pop (album)">King of Pop</a>,</i> with different tracklists for different regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[288]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NeverlandRides.jpg"><img alt="A view from above of a large property in a semi-desert. The landscape is pale with clumps of vegetation. The property shows circular structures between the buildings." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="322" data-file-width="550" decoding="async" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/NeverlandRides.jpg/220px-NeverlandRides.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/NeverlandRides.jpg/330px-NeverlandRides.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/NeverlandRides.jpg/440px-NeverlandRides.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:NeverlandRides.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An aerial view of part of Jackson's 2,800-acre (11 km<sup>2</sup>) Neverland Valley Ranch near Los Olivos, California, showing the rides</div></div></div>
<p>In 2008, Fortress Investments threatened to <a href="/wiki/Foreclosure" title="Foreclosure">foreclose</a> on Neverland Ranch, which Jackson had used as collateral for his loans. Fortress sold Jackson's debts to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colony_Capital" title="Colony Capital">Colony Capital</a> LLC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[289]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[290]</a></sup> In November, Jackson transferred Neverland Ranch's title to Sycamore Valley Ranch Company LLC, a joint venture between Jackson and Colony Capital LLC. The deal earned him <span class="nowrap">$35 million</span>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[291]</a></sup> Jackson arranged to sell a collection of his memorabilia of more than 1,000 items through <a href="/wiki/Julien%27s_Auctions" title="Julien's Auctions">Julien's Auction House</a>. On the eve of the first public exhibit, Jackson canceled the auction after earning between $200<span class="nowrap"> </span>million to $300<span class="nowrap"> </span>million of initial sales from a series of concerts to be held in London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[292]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-indie-auction_272-1"><a href="#cite_note-indie-auction-272">[270]</a></sup>
</p><p>In March 2009, amid speculation about his finances and health, Jackson announced a series of comeback concerts, <a href="/wiki/This_Is_It_(concert_residency)" title="This Is It (concert residency)">This Is It</a>, at a press conference at <a href="/wiki/The_O2_Arena" title="The O2 Arena">The O2 Arena</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[293]</a></sup> The shows were to be his first major concerts since the HIStory World Tour in 1997. Jackson suggested he would retire after the shows. The initial plan was for 10 concerts in London, followed by shows in Paris, New York City and Mumbai. Randy Phillips, president and chief executive of <a href="/wiki/Anschutz_Entertainment_Group" title="Anschutz Entertainment Group">AEG Live</a>, predicted the first 10 dates would earn Jackson £50<span class="nowrap"> </span>million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[294]</a></sup> The London residency was increased to 50 dates after record-breaking ticket sales; over one million were sold in less than two hours.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[295]</a></sup> The concerts were to run from July 13, 2009, to March 6, 2010. Jackson moved to Los Angeles, where he rehearsed in the weeks leading up to the tour under the direction of choreographer <a href="/wiki/Kenny_Ortega" title="Kenny Ortega">Kenny Ortega</a>, whom he had worked with during his previous tours. Rehearsals took place at <a href="/wiki/Kia_Forum" title="Kia Forum">the Forum</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Staples_Center" title="Staples Center">Staples Center</a> owned by AEG.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[296]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Death">Death</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Death_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Death of Michael Jackson">Death of Michael Jackson</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_Star.JPG"><img alt="Jackson's Star with flowers and notes on it" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3168" data-file-width="4752" decoding="async" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Michael_Jackson_Star.JPG/170px-Michael_Jackson_Star.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Michael_Jackson_Star.JPG/255px-Michael_Jackson_Star.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Michael_Jackson_Star.JPG/340px-Michael_Jackson_Star.JPG 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_Star.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Fans placed flowers and notes on Jackson's star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame on the day of his death</div></div></div>
<p>On June 25, 2009, less than three weeks before the first <i><a href="/wiki/This_Is_It_(concert_residency)" title="This Is It (concert residency)">This Is It</a></i> show was due to begin in London, with all concerts sold out, Jackson died from <a href="/wiki/Cardiac_arrest" title="Cardiac arrest">cardiac arrest</a>, caused by a propofol and benzodiazepine overdose.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[297]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNN_300-0"><a href="#cite_note-CNN-300">[298]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Conrad_Murray" title="Conrad Murray">Conrad Murray</a>, his personal physician, had given Jackson various medications to help him sleep at his rented mansion in <a href="/wiki/Holmby_Hills,_Los_Angeles" title="Holmby Hills, Los Angeles">Holmby Hills, Los Angeles</a>. Paramedics received a <a href="/wiki/9-1-1" title="9-1-1">911</a> call at 12:22 pm <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Time_Zone" title="Pacific Time Zone">Pacific time</a> (19:22 UTC) and arrived three minutes later.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[299]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[300]</a></sup> Jackson was not breathing and <a href="/wiki/Cardiopulmonary_resuscitation" title="Cardiopulmonary resuscitation">CPR</a> was performed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[301]</a></sup> Resuscitation efforts continued en route to <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan_UCLA_Medical_Center" title="Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center">Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center</a>, and for more than an hour after Jackson's arrival there, but were unsuccessful,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[302]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Times_305-0"><a href="#cite_note-Times-305">[303]</a></sup> and Jackson was pronounced dead at 2:26 pm Pacific time (21:26 UTC).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Telegraph_306-0"><a href="#cite_note-Telegraph-306">[304]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[305]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jackson was administered <a href="/wiki/Propofol" title="Propofol">propofol</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lorazepam" title="Lorazepam">lorazepam</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Midazolam" title="Midazolam">midazolam</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[306]</a></sup> his death was caused by a propofol overdose.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNN_300-1"><a href="#cite_note-CNN-300">[298]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Times_305-1"><a href="#cite_note-Times-305">[303]</a></sup> News of his death spread quickly online, causing websites to slow down and <a href="/wiki/Crash_(computing)" title="Crash (computing)">crash</a> from user overload,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[307]</a></sup> and putting unprecedented strain<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wood_310-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wood-310">[308]</a></sup> on services and websites including <a href="/wiki/Google_Search" title="Google Search">Google</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shiels_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-Shiels-311">[309]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/AOL_Instant_Messenger" title="AOL Instant Messenger">AOL Instant Messenger</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wood_310-1"><a href="#cite_note-Wood-310">[308]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Twitter" title="Twitter">Twitter</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia" title="Wikipedia">Wikipedia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shiels_311-1"><a href="#cite_note-Shiels-311">[309]</a></sup> Overall, <a href="/wiki/Web_traffic" title="Web traffic">web traffic</a> rose by between 11% and 20%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-crash_312-0"><a href="#cite_note-crash-312">[310]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[311]</a></sup> MTV and <a href="/wiki/BET" title="BET">BET</a> aired <a href="/wiki/Marathon_(media)" title="Marathon (media)">marathons</a> of Jackson's music videos,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[312]</a></sup> and Jackson specials aired on television stations around the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[313]</a></sup> MTV briefly returned to its original music video format,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Barnes_13-1"><a href="#cite_note-Barnes-13">[11]</a></sup> and aired hours of Jackson's music videos, with live news specials featuring reactions from MTV personalities and other celebrities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tylerc_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-Tylerc-316">[314]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Memorial_service">Memorial service</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson_memorial_service" title="Michael Jackson memorial service">Michael Jackson memorial service</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_Grave.jpg"><img alt="A large pink/cream-colored box in front of a stained glass window." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3264" data-file-width="2448" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Michael_Jackson_Grave.jpg/170px-Michael_Jackson_Grave.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Michael_Jackson_Grave.jpg/255px-Michael_Jackson_Grave.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Michael_Jackson_Grave.jpg/340px-Michael_Jackson_Grave.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_Grave.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jackson's unmarked crypt at the end of the Sanctuary of Ascension in the Holly Terrace of the Great Mausoleum, Forest Lawn Glendale</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Neverland-ranch-memorial.jpg"><img alt="A group of people standing outside a gated area. There are trees, bushes, and grassed areas. A majority of the area the people and in are shadowed by the trees by the gate." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="422" data-file-width="700" decoding="async" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Neverland-ranch-memorial.jpg/250px-Neverland-ranch-memorial.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Neverland-ranch-memorial.jpg/375px-Neverland-ranch-memorial.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Neverland-ranch-memorial.jpg/500px-Neverland-ranch-memorial.jpg 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Neverland-ranch-memorial.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Fans visiting the makeshift memorial set up outside the Neverland Ranch entrance shortly after Jackson's death</div></div></div>
<p>Jackson's memorial was held on July 7, 2009, at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Staples_Center" title="Staples Center">Staples Center</a> in Los Angeles, preceded by a private family service at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Forest_Lawn_Memorial_Park,_Hollywood_Hills#Court_of_Liberty" title="Forest Lawn Memorial Park, Hollywood Hills">Forest Lawn Memorial Park's Hall of Liberty</a>. Over 1.6<span class="nowrap"> </span>million fans applied for tickets to the memorial; the 8,750 recipients were drawn at random, and each received two tickets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[315]</a></sup> The memorial service was one of the most watched events in <a href="/wiki/Streaming_media" title="Streaming media">streaming</a> history,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[316]</a></sup> with an estimated US audience of 31.1<span class="nowrap"> </span>million<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[317]</a></sup> and a worldwide audience of an estimated 2.5 to 3 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[318]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Mariah_Carey" title="Mariah Carey">Mariah Carey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stevie_Wonder" title="Stevie Wonder">Stevie Wonder</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lionel_Richie" title="Lionel Richie">Lionel Richie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jennifer_Hudson" title="Jennifer Hudson">Jennifer Hudson</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Shaheen_Jafargholi" title="Shaheen Jafargholi">Shaheen Jafargholi</a> performed at the memorial, and <a href="/wiki/Smokey_Robinson" title="Smokey Robinson">Smokey Robinson</a> and <a href="/wiki/Queen_Latifah" title="Queen Latifah">Queen Latifah</a> gave eulogies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[319]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Al_Sharpton" title="Al Sharpton">Al Sharpton</a> received a standing ovation with cheers when he told Jackson's children: "Wasn't nothing strange about your daddy. It was strange what your daddy had to deal with. But he dealt with it anyway."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[320]</a></sup> Jackson's 11-year-old daughter <a href="/wiki/Paris_Jackson" title="Paris Jackson">Paris Katherine</a>, speaking publicly for the first time, wept as she addressed the crowd.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[321]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[322]</a></sup> The Rev. Lucious Smith provided a closing prayer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[323]</a></sup> Jackson's body was entombed on September 3, 2009, at <a href="/wiki/Forest_Lawn_Memorial_Park_(Glendale)" title="Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Glendale)">Forest Lawn Memorial Park</a> in <a href="/wiki/Glendale,_California" title="Glendale, California">Glendale, California</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[324]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Criminal_investigation_and_prosecution_of_Conrad_Murray">Criminal investigation and prosecution of Conrad Murray</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/People_v._Murray" title="People v. Murray">People v. Murray</a></div>
<p>In August 2009, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_County_Coroner" title="Los Angeles County Coroner">Los Angeles County Coroner</a> ruled that Jackson's death was a <a href="/wiki/Homicide" title="Homicide">homicide</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[325]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[326]</a></sup> Law enforcement officials <a href="/wiki/People_v._Murray" title="People v. Murray">charged Murray</a> with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Involuntary_manslaughter" title="Involuntary manslaughter">involuntary manslaughter</a> on February 8, 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[327]</a></sup> In late 2011, he was found guilty of involuntary manslaughter<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[328]</a></sup> and held without bail to await sentencing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[329]</a></sup> Murray was sentenced to four years in prison.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[330]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Posthumous_sales">Posthumous sales</span></h3>
<p>At the <a href="/wiki/American_Music_Awards_of_2009" title="American Music Awards of 2009">2009 American Music Awards</a>, Jackson won four posthumous awards, including two for his compilation album <i><a href="/wiki/Number_Ones_(Michael_Jackson_album)" title="Number Ones (Michael Jackson album)">Number Ones</a></i>, bringing his total American Music Awards to 26.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[331]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[332]</a></sup> In the year after his death, more than 16.1<span class="nowrap"> </span>million of Jackson's albums sold in the US and 35<span class="nowrap"> </span>million albums sold worldwide, more than any other artist in 2009.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[333]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[334]</a></sup> He became the first artist to sell one million <a href="/wiki/Music_download" title="Music download">music downloads</a> in a week, with 2.6<span class="nowrap"> </span>million song downloads. <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Thriller_(Michael_Jackson_album)" title="Thriller (Michael Jackson album)">Thriller</a></i>, <i>Number Ones</i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Essential_Michael_Jackson" title="The Essential Michael Jackson">The Essential Michael Jackson</a></i> became the first catalog albums to outsell any new album.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[335]</a></sup> Jackson also became the first artist to have four of the top 20 best-selling albums in a single year in the US.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[336]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the surge in sales, in March 2010, Sony Music signed a $250<span class="nowrap"> </span>million deal (equivalent to $310,659,240 in 2021) with the Jackson estate to extend their distribution rights to Jackson's back catalog until at least 2017; it had been due to expire in 2015. It was the most expensive music contract for a single artist in history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sony_339-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sony-339">[337]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[338]</a></sup> They agreed to release ten albums of previously unreleased material and new collections of released work.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sony_339-1"><a href="#cite_note-Sony-339">[337]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[339]</a></sup> The deal was extended in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[340]</a></sup> That July, a Los Angeles court awarded <a href="/wiki/Quincy_Jones" title="Quincy Jones">Quincy Jones</a> $9.4<span class="nowrap"> </span>million of disputed royalty payments for <i>Off the Wall</i>, <i>Thriller</i>, and <i>Bad</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Who's_Bad_58-1"><a href="#cite_note-Who's_Bad-58">[56]</a></sup> In July 2018, Sony/ATV bought the estate's stake in EMI for $287.5<span class="nowrap"> </span>million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[341]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2014, Jackson became the first artist to have a top ten single in the <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100 in five different decades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[342]</a></sup> The following year, <i>Thriller</i> became the first album to be certified for 30<span class="nowrap"> </span>million shipments by the <a href="/wiki/Recording_Industry_Association_of_America" title="Recording Industry Association of America">RIAA</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RIAA_8-1"><a href="#cite_note-RIAA-8">[7]</a></sup> a year later, it was certified 33× platinum, after <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soundscan" title="Soundscan">Soundscan</a> added streams and audio downloads to album certifications.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Certified_345-0"><a href="#cite_note-Certified-345">[343]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[nb 3]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Posthumous_releases_and_productions">Posthumous releases and productions</span></h3>
<p>The first posthumous Jackson song, "<a href="/wiki/This_Is_It_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="This Is It (Michael Jackson song)">This Is It</a>", co-written in the 1980s with <a href="/wiki/Paul_Anka" title="Paul Anka">Paul Anka</a>, was released in October 2009. The surviving Jackson brothers reunited to record backing vocals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[345]</a></sup> It was followed by a documentary film about the rehearsals for the canceled This Is It tour, <i><a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson%27s_This_Is_It" title="Michael Jackson's This Is It">Michael Jackson's This Is It</a>,</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[346]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson%27s_This_Is_It_(album)" title="Michael Jackson's This Is It (album)">a compilation album</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[347]</a></sup> Despite a limited two-week engagement, the film became the highest-grossing documentary or concert film ever, with earnings of more than <span class="nowrap">$260 million</span> worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[348]</a></sup> Jackson's estate received 90% of the profits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[349]</a></sup> In late 2010, Sony released the first posthumous album, <i><a href="/wiki/Michael_(album)" title="Michael (album)">Michael</a></i>, and the promotional single "<a href="/wiki/Breaking_News_(song)" title="Breaking News (song)">Breaking News</a>". Jackson collaborator will.i.am expressed disgust, saying that Jackson would not have approved the release.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[350]</a></sup>
</p><p>Video game developer <a href="/wiki/Ubisoft" title="Ubisoft">Ubisoft</a> released a <a href="/wiki/Music_video_game" title="Music video game">music video game</a> featuring Jackson for the 2010 holiday season, <i><a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson:_The_Experience" title="Michael Jackson: The Experience">Michael Jackson: The Experience</a>;</i> it was among the first games to use <a href="/wiki/Kinect" title="Kinect">Kinect</a> and <a href="/wiki/PlayStation_Move" title="PlayStation Move">PlayStation Move</a>, the motion-detecting camera systems for <a href="/wiki/Xbox_360" title="Xbox 360">Xbox 360</a> and <a href="/wiki/PlayStation_3" title="PlayStation 3">PlayStation 3</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[351]</a></sup>
</p><p>In April 2011, <a href="/wiki/Mohamed_Al-Fayed" title="Mohamed Al-Fayed">Mohamed Al-Fayed</a>, chairman of <a href="/wiki/Fulham_F.C." title="Fulham F.C.">Fulham Football Club</a>, unveiled a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fulham_statue_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Fulham statue of Michael Jackson">statue of Jackson</a> outside the club stadium, <a href="/wiki/Craven_Cottage" title="Craven Cottage">Craven Cottage</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fulham_355-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fulham-355">[352]</a></sup> It was moved to the <a href="/wiki/National_Football_Museum" title="National Football Museum">National Football Museum</a> in Manchester in May 2014,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[353]</a></sup> and removed from display in March 2019 following renewed sexual assault allegations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[354]</a></sup>
