</p><p>In October 2011, the theater company <a href="/wiki/Cirque_du_Soleil" title="Cirque du Soleil">Cirque du Soleil</a> launched <i><a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson:_The_Immortal_World_Tour" title="Michael Jackson: The Immortal World Tour">Michael Jackson: The Immortal World Tour</a>,</i> a $57-million production,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[355]</a></sup> in Montreal, with a permanent show <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Residency_show" title="Residency show">resident</a> in Las Vegas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[356]</a></sup> A larger and more theatrical Cirque show, <i><a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson:_One" title="Michael Jackson: One">Michael Jackson: One</a>,</i> designed for residency at the <a href="/wiki/Mandalay_Bay" title="Mandalay Bay">Mandalay Bay</a> resort in Las Vegas, opened on May 23, 2013, in a renovated theater.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[357]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[358]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2012, in an attempt to end a family dispute, Jackson's brother <a href="/wiki/Jermaine_Jackson" title="Jermaine Jackson">Jermaine</a> retracted his signature on a public letter criticizing executors of Jackson's estate and his mother's advisors over the legitimacy of his brother's will.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[359]</a></sup> T.J. Jackson, son of Tito Jackson, was given co-guardianship of Michael Jackson's children after false reports of Katherine Jackson going missing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[360]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Xscape_(album)" title="Xscape (album)">Xscape</a></i>, an album of unreleased material, was released on May 13, 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[361]</a></sup> A duet between Jackson and <a href="/wiki/Justin_Timberlake" title="Justin Timberlake">Justin Timberlake</a> titled "<a href="/wiki/Love_Never_Felt_So_Good" title="Love Never Felt So Good">Love Never Felt So Good</a>" was released in 2014, making Jackson the first artist to have a top 10 single on the US <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100 in five different decades when the single reached number 9.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[362]</a></sup> Later that year, <a href="/wiki/Queen_(band)" title="Queen (band)">Queen</a> released a duet recorded with Jackson and Freddie Mercury in the 1980s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Greene_72-1"><a href="#cite_note-Greene-72">[70]</a></sup> A compilation album, <i><a href="/wiki/Scream_(Michael_Jackson_album)" title="Scream (Michael Jackson album)">Scream</a></i>, was released on September 29, 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[363]</a></sup>
</p><p>In November 2019, it was reported that a Jackson biopic, produced by <i><a href="/wiki/Bohemian_Rhapsody_(film)" title="Bohemian Rhapsody (film)">Bohemian Rhapsody</a></i> (2018) producer <a href="/wiki/Graham_King" title="Graham King">Graham King</a>, was in the works, with the screenplay written by <a href="/wiki/John_Logan_(writer)" title="John Logan (writer)">John Logan</a>. Jackson's estate granted King the rights to his music and will work with King.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[364]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Jukebox_musical" title="Jukebox musical">jukebox musical</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/MJ_the_Musical" title="MJ the Musical">MJ the Musical</a></i>, premiered on Broadway in 2022.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[365]</a></sup> Actor <a href="/wiki/Myles_Frost" title="Myles Frost">Myles Frost</a> won the 2022 <a href="/wiki/Tony_Award_for_Best_Actor_in_a_Musical" title="Tony Award for Best Actor in a Musical">Tony Award for Best Actor in a Musical</a> for his portrayal of Jackson.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[366]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Posthumous_child_sexual_abuse_allegations">Posthumous child sexual abuse allegations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Leaving_Neverland" title="Leaving Neverland">Leaving Neverland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Square_One:_Michael_Jackson" title="Square One: Michael Jackson">Square One: Michael Jackson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Neverland_Firsthand:_Investigating_the_Michael_Jackson_Documentary" title="Neverland Firsthand: Investigating the Michael Jackson Documentary">Neverland Firsthand: Investigating the Michael Jackson Documentary</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson:_Chase_the_Truth" title="Michael Jackson: Chase the Truth">Michael Jackson: Chase the Truth</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michaeljackson1.jpg"><img alt="A smiling Jackson wears a blue baseball cap and a red shirt. On his right are two women. One holds a pen, and one holds a small purse. On his left, a young boy looks off-camera. He is dressed in a red shirt, too. Jackson's hand is on his shoulder." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="582" data-file-width="877" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Michaeljackson1.jpg/220px-Michaeljackson1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Michaeljackson1.jpg/330px-Michaeljackson1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Michaeljackson1.jpg/440px-Michaeljackson1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michaeljackson1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jackson and Safechuck (right) in Honolulu, Hawaii in 1988</div></div></div>
<p>In 2013, choreographer <a href="/wiki/Wade_Robson" title="Wade Robson">Wade Robson</a> filed a lawsuit alleging that Jackson had sexually abused him for seven years, beginning when he was seven years old (1989–1996).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[367]</a></sup> In 2014, a case was filed by James Safechuck, alleging sexual abuse over a four-year period from the age of ten (1988–1992).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[368]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[369]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-indie_abuse_373-0"><a href="#cite_note-indie_abuse-373">[370]</a></sup> Both had testified in Jackson's defense during the 1993 allegations; Robson did so again in 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[371]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[372]</a></sup> In 2015, Robson's case against Jackson's estate was dismissed on the grounds of being filed too late. Safechuck's claim was also time-barred.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[373]</a></sup> In 2017, it was ruled that Jackson's corporations could not be held accountable for his alleged past actions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[374]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[375]</a></sup> The rulings were appealed, and on October 20, 2020, Safechuck's lawsuit against Jackson's corporations was again dismissed, with the presiding judge ruling that there was no evidence that Safechuck had a relationship with Jackson's companies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[376]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[377]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[378]</a></sup> On April 26, 2021, Robson's case was dismissed because of a lack of supporting evidence that the defendants exercised control over Jackson.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[379]</a></sup>
</p><p>Robson and Safechuck described allegations in graphic detail in the documentary <i>Leaving Neverland</i>, released in March 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[380]</a></sup> Radio stations in New Zealand, Canada, the UK and the Netherlands removed Jackson's music from their playlists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PR_blitz_384-0"><a href="#cite_note-PR_blitz-384">[381]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[382]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[383]</a></sup> Jackson's family condemned the film as a "public lynching",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[384]</a></sup> and the Jackson estate released a statement calling the film a "tabloid character assassination [Jackson] endured in life, and now in death".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[385]</a></sup> Close associates of Jackson, such as <a href="/wiki/Corey_Feldman" title="Corey Feldman">Corey Feldman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aaron_Carter" title="Aaron Carter">Aaron Carter</a>, Brett Barnes, and <a href="/wiki/Macaulay_Culkin" title="Macaulay Culkin">Macaulay Culkin</a>, said that Jackson had not molested them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[386]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[387]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[388]</a></sup> Rebuttal documentaries, such as <i>Square One: Michael Jackson</i>, <i>Neverland Firsthand: Investigating the Michael Jackson Documentary</i> and <i>Michael Jackson: Chase the Truth</i>, presented information countering the claims suggested by <i>Leaving Neverland</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[389]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[390]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[391]</a></sup> Jackson's album sales increased following the documentary screenings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[392]</a></sup> <i>Billboard</i> senior editor Gail Mitchell said she and a colleague interviewed about thirty music executives who believed Jackson's legacy could withstand the controversy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[393]</a></sup> In late 2019, some New Zealand and Canadian radio stations re-added Jackson's music to their playlists, citing "positive listener survey results".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[394]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[395]</a></sup>
</p><p>On February 21, 2019, the Jackson estate sued HBO for breaching a non-disparagement clause from a 1992 contract. The suit sought to compel HBO to participate in a non-confidential arbitration that could result in $100<span class="nowrap"> </span>million or more in damages rewarded to the estate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[396]</a></sup> HBO said they did not breach a contract and filed an anti-<a href="/wiki/Strategic_lawsuit_against_public_participation" title="Strategic lawsuit against public participation">SLAPP</a> motion against the estate. In September 2019, Judge <a href="/wiki/George_H._Wu" title="George H. Wu">George H. Wu</a> denied HBO's motion to dismiss the case, allowing the Jackson estate to arbitrate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[397]</a></sup> HBO appealed, but in December 2020 the appeals court affirmed Wu's ruling.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[398]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy">Legacy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Cultural_impact_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Cultural impact of Michael Jackson">Cultural impact of Michael Jackson</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Michael_Jackson_records_and_achievements" title="List of Michael Jackson records and achievements">List of Michael Jackson records and achievements</a></div> <div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rest_In_Peace_Michael_Jackson._King_of_Pop.cropped.jpg"><img alt="A wall with colorful graffiti depicting Michael Jackson; once his full body dancing, then a close-up of his face." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="618" data-file-width="1023" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Rest_In_Peace_Michael_Jackson._King_of_Pop.cropped.jpg/220px-Rest_In_Peace_Michael_Jackson._King_of_Pop.cropped.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Rest_In_Peace_Michael_Jackson._King_of_Pop.cropped.jpg/330px-Rest_In_Peace_Michael_Jackson._King_of_Pop.cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Rest_In_Peace_Michael_Jackson._King_of_Pop.cropped.jpg/440px-Rest_In_Peace_Michael_Jackson._King_of_Pop.cropped.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Rest_In_Peace_Michael_Jackson._King_of_Pop.cropped.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Michael Jackson graffiti in <a href="/wiki/Santa_Cruz,_California" title="Santa Cruz, California">Santa Cruz, California</a></div></div></div><p> Jackson has been referred to as the "<a href="/wiki/Honorific_nicknames_in_popular_music" title="Honorific nicknames in popular music">King of Pop</a>" for having transformed the art of music videos and paving the way for modern pop music. For much of Jackson's career, he had an unparalleled worldwide influence over the younger generation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ADL_225-1"><a href="#cite_note-ADL-225">[223]</a></sup> His influence extended beyond the music industry; he impacted dance, led fashion trends, and raised awareness for global affairs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[399]</a></sup> Jackson's music and videos fostered racial diversity in MTV's roster and steered its focus from rock to pop music and R&amp;B, shaping the channel into a form that proved enduring.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYoung200925_46-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYoung200925-46">[44]</a></sup> In songs such as "<a href="/wiki/Man_in_the_Mirror" title="Man in the Mirror">Man in the Mirror</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Black_or_White" title="Black or White">Black or White</a>", <a href="/wiki/Heal_the_World" title="Heal the World">Heal the World</a>, "<a href="/wiki/Earth_Song" title="Earth Song">Earth Song</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/They_Don%27t_Care_About_Us" title="They Don't Care About Us">They Don't Care About Us</a>", Jackson's music emphasized <a href="/wiki/Racial_integration" title="Racial integration">racial integration</a> and <a href="/wiki/Environmentalism" title="Environmentalism">environmentalism</a> and protested injustice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[400]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[401]</a></sup> He is recognized as the Most Successful Entertainer of All Time by <i><a href="/wiki/Guinness_World_Records" title="Guinness World Records">Guinness World Records</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CityNews_405-0"><a href="#cite_note-CityNews-405">[402]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ditzian_406-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ditzian-406">[403]</a></sup> He is considered one of the most significant cultural icons of the 20th century,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[404]</a></sup> and his contributions to music, dance, and fashion, along with his publicized personal life, made him a global figure in popular culture for over four decades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[405]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[406]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[407]</a></sup><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r996844942">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style></p><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Trying to trace Michael Jackson's influence on the pop stars that followed him is like trying to trace the influence of oxygen and gravity. So vast, far-reaching and was his impact—particularly in the wake of <i><a href="/wiki/Thriller_(album)" title="Thriller (album)">Thriller</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s colossal and heretofore unmatched commercial success—that there weren't a whole lot of artists who <i>weren't</i> trying to mimic some of the Jackson formula.</p><div class="templatequotecite">— <cite>J. Edward Keyes of <i><a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stone" title="Rolling Stone">Rolling Stone</a></i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[408]</a></sup></cite></div></blockquote> <p><a href="/wiki/Danyel_Smith" title="Danyel Smith">Danyel Smith</a>, chief content officer of Vibe Media Group and the editor-in-chief of <i><a href="/wiki/Vibe_(magazine)" title="Vibe (magazine)">Vibe</a>,</i> described Jackson as "the Greatest Star".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[409]</a></sup> Steve Huey of AllMusic called him "an unstoppable juggernaut, possessed of all the skills to dominate the charts seemingly at will: an instantly identifiable voice, eye-popping dance moves, stunning musical versatility and loads of sheer star power".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_12-2"><a href="#cite_note-allmusic-12">[10]</a></sup> BET said Jackson was "quite simply the greatest entertainer of all time" whose "sound, style, movement and legacy continues to inspire artists of all genres".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[410]</a></sup>
</p><div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1337" data-file-width="1061" decoding="async" height="214" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Michael_Jackson.jpg/170px-Michael_Jackson.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Michael_Jackson.jpg/255px-Michael_Jackson.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Michael_Jackson.jpg/340px-Michael_Jackson.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jackson's <i>Bad</i> era wax figure at <a href="/wiki/Madame_Tussauds" title="Madame Tussauds">Madame Tussauds</a>, London in 1992</div></div></div>
<p>In 1984, <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i> pop critic <a href="/wiki/Jay_Cocks" title="Jay Cocks">Jay Cocks</a> wrote that "Jackson is the biggest thing since the Beatles. He is the hottest single phenomenon since Elvis Presley. He just may be the most popular black singer ever." He described Jackson as a "star of records, radio, rock video. A one-man rescue team for the music business. A songwriter who sets the beat for a decade. A dancer with the fanciest feet on the street. A singer who cuts across all boundaries of taste and style, and color too."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Time_93-2"><a href="#cite_note-Time-93">[91]</a></sup> In 2003, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph" title="The Daily Telegraph">The Daily Telegraph</a></i> writer <a href="/wiki/Tom_Utley" title="Tom Utley">Tom Utley</a> described Jackson as "extremely important" and a "genius".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[411]</a></sup> At Jackson's memorial service on July 7, 2009, Motown founder Berry Gordy called Jackson "the greatest entertainer that ever lived".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[412]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[413]</a></sup> In a June 28, 2009 <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baltimore_Sun" title="Baltimore Sun">Baltimore Sun</a></i> article, Jill Rosen wrote that Jackson's legacy influenced fields including sound, dance, fashion, music videos and celebrity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417"><a href="#cite_note-417">[414]</a></sup>
</p><p>Pop critic <a href="/wiki/Robert_Christgau" title="Robert Christgau">Robert Christgau</a> wrote that Jackson's work from the 1970s to the early 1990s showed "immense originality, adaptability, and ambition" with "genius beats, hooks, arrangements, and vocals (though not lyrics)", music that "will stand forever as a reproach to the puritanical notion that pop music is slick or shallow and that's the end of it". During the 1990s, as Jackson lost control of his "troubling life", his music suffered and began to shape "an arc not merely of promise fulfilled and outlived, but of something approaching tragedy: a phenomenally ebullient child star tops himself like none before, only to transmute audibly into a lost weirdo".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[415]</a></sup> In the 2000s, Christgau wrote: "Jackson's obsession with fame, his grotesque life magnified by his grotesque wealth, are such an offense to rock aesthetes that the fact that he's a great musician is now often forgotten".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[416]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Philanthropy_and_humanitarian_work">Philanthropy and humanitarian work</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Philanthropy_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Philanthropy of Michael Jackson">Philanthropy of Michael Jackson</a></div>
<p>Jackson is regarded as a prolific philanthropist and humanitarian.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Daunt_420-0"><a href="#cite_note-Daunt-420">[417]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jackson_Lee_421-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jackson_Lee-421">[418]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cafarelli_422-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cafarelli-422">[419]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[420]</a></sup> Jackson's early charitable work has been described by <i><a href="/wiki/The_Chronicle_of_Philanthropy" title="The Chronicle of Philanthropy">The Chronicle of Philanthropy</a></i> as having "paved the way for the current surge in celebrity philanthropy",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Philanthropy_424-0"><a href="#cite_note-Philanthropy-424">[421]</a></sup> and by the <i><a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times" title="Los Angeles Times">Los Angeles Times</a></i> as having "set the standard for generosity for other entertainers".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Daunt_420-1"><a href="#cite_note-Daunt-420">[417]</a></sup> 
By some estimates, he donated over $500 million, not accounting for inflation, to various charities over the course of his life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Daunt_420-2"><a href="#cite_note-Daunt-420">[417]</a></sup> The total monetary value of Jackson’s donations may be substantially higher since Jackson often gave anonymously and without fanfare. In addition to supporting several charities established by others, in 1992 Jackson established his <a href="/wiki/Heal_the_World_Foundation" title="Heal the World Foundation">Heal the World Foundation</a>, to which he donated several million dollars in revenue from his <a href="/wiki/Dangerous_World_Tour" title="Dangerous World Tour">Dangerous World Tour</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[422]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jackson's philanthropic activities went beyond just monetary donations. He also performed at <a href="/wiki/Benefit_concert" title="Benefit concert">benefit concerts</a>, some of which he arranged. He gifted tickets for his regular concert performances to groups that assist underprivileged children. He visited sick children in hospitals around the world. He opened his own home for visits by underprivileged or sick children and provided special facilities and nurses if the children needed that level of care.
</p><p>Jackson donated valuable, personal and professional paraphernalia for numerous charity auctions. He received various awards and accolades for his philanthropic work, including two bestowed by Presidents of the United States. The vast breadth of Jackson’s philanthropic work has earned recognition in the <a href="/wiki/Guinness_World_Records" title="Guinness World Records">Guinness World Records</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Daunt_420-3"><a href="#cite_note-Daunt-420">[417]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Telegraph-2001_426-0"><a href="#cite_note-Telegraph-2001-426">[423]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Guinness_427-0"><a href="#cite_note-Guinness-427">[424]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Artistry">Artistry</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Influences">Influences</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson%27s_%22Bad%22_Jacket_and_Belt.jpg"><img alt="A black jacket with five round golden medals on its left and right shoulders, a gold band on its left arm sleeve, and two belt straps on the right bottom sleeve. Underneath the jacket is a golden belt, with a round ornament in its center." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2318" data-file-width="2047" decoding="async" height="193" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Michael_Jackson%27s_%22Bad%22_Jacket_and_Belt.jpg/170px-Michael_Jackson%27s_%22Bad%22_Jacket_and_Belt.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Michael_Jackson%27s_%22Bad%22_Jacket_and_Belt.jpg/256px-Michael_Jackson%27s_%22Bad%22_Jacket_and_Belt.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Michael_Jackson%27s_%22Bad%22_Jacket_and_Belt.jpg/341px-Michael_Jackson%27s_%22Bad%22_Jacket_and_Belt.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson%27s_%22Bad%22_Jacket_and_Belt.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jackson's <i>Bad</i> era jacket on display at the <a href="/wiki/Hollywood,_Los_Angeles" title="Hollywood, Los Angeles">Hollywood</a> <a href="/wiki/Guinness_World_Records#Museums" title="Guinness World Records"><i>Guinness World Records</i> Museum</a></div></div></div><p>Jackson was influenced by musicians including <a href="/wiki/James_Brown" title="James Brown">James Brown</a>, <a href="/wiki/Little_Richard" title="Little Richard">Little Richard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jackie_Wilson" title="Jackie Wilson">Jackie Wilson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diana_Ross" title="Diana Ross">Diana Ross</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fred_Astaire" title="Fred Astaire">Fred Astaire</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sammy_Davis_Jr" title="Sammy Davis Jr">Sammy Davis Jr</a>., <a href="/wiki/Gene_Kelly" title="Gene Kelly">Gene Kelly</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tucker_428-0"><a href="#cite_note-Tucker-428">[425]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/David_Ruffin" title="David Ruffin">David Ruffin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[426]</a></sup> Little Richard had a substantial influence on Jackson,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[427]</a></sup> but Brown was his greatest inspiration; he later said that as a small child, his mother would wake him whenever Brown appeared on television. Jackson described being "mesmerized".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[428]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jackson's vocal technique was influenced by Diana Ross; his use of the <i>oooh</i> interjection from a young age was something Ross had used on many of her songs with <a href="/wiki/The_Supremes" title="The Supremes">the Supremes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli200964_432-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli200964-432">[429]</a></sup> She was a mother figure to him, and he often watched her rehearse.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[430]</a></sup> He said he had learned a lot from watching how she moved and sang, and that she had encouraged him to have confidence in himself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli200960_434-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli200960-434">[431]</a></sup>
</p><p>Choreographer <a href="/wiki/David_Winters_(choreographer)" title="David Winters (choreographer)">David Winters</a>, who met Jackson while choreographing the 1971 Diana Ross TV special <i><a href="/wiki/Diana!" title="Diana!">Diana!</a></i>, said that Jackson watched the musical <i><a href="/wiki/West_Side_Story_(1961_film)" title="West Side Story (1961 film)">West Side Story</a></i> almost every week, and it was his favorite film; he paid tribute to it in "Beat It" and the "Bad" video.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewis_Jones20056,_54_435-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewis_Jones20056,_54-435">[432]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[433]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[434]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Vocal_style">Vocal style</span></h3>
<p>Jackson sang from childhood, and over time his voice and vocal style changed. Between 1971 and 1975, his voice descended from boy <a href="/wiki/Soprano" title="Soprano">soprano</a> to high <a href="/wiki/Tenor" title="Tenor">tenor</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrackettHoard2004414_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrackettHoard2004414-438">[435]</a></sup> He was known for his vocal range.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[436]</a></sup> With the arrival of <i>Off the Wall</i> in the late 1970s, Jackson's abilities as a vocalist were well regarded; <i>Rolling Stone</i> compared his vocals to the "breathless, dreamy stutter" of Stevie Wonder, and wrote that "Jackson's feathery-timbred tenor is extraordinarily beautiful. It slides smoothly into a startling <a href="/wiki/Falsetto" title="Falsetto">falsetto</a> that's used very daringly."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[437]</a></sup> By the time of 1982's <i>Thriller</i>, <i>Rolling Stone</i> wrote that Jackson was singing in a "fully adult voice" that was "tinged by sadness".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thriller_441-0"><a href="#cite_note-Thriller-441">[438]</a></sup>
</p><p>The turn of the 1990s saw the release of the introspective album <i>Dangerous</i>. <i>The New York Times</i> noted that on some tracks, "he gulps for breath, his voice quivers with anxiety or drops to a desperate whisper, hissing through clenched teeth" and he had a "wretched tone". When singing of brotherhood or self-esteem the musician would return to "smooth" vocals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_Dangerous_442-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT_Dangerous-442">[439]</a></sup> Of <i>Invincible</i>, <i>Rolling Stone</i> wrote that, at 43, Jackson still performed "exquisitely voiced rhythm tracks and vibrating vocal harmonies".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[440]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Vogel" title="Joseph Vogel">Joseph Vogel</a> notes Jackson's ability to use non-verbal sounds to express emotion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVogel20129_444-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVogel20129-444">[441]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Neil_McCormick" title="Neil McCormick">Neil McCormick</a> wrote that Jackson's unorthodox singing style "was original and utterly distinctive".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[442]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Musicianship">Musicianship</span></h3>
<p>Jackson had no formal music training and could not read or write <a href="/wiki/Musical_notation" title="Musical notation">music notation</a>. He is credited for playing guitar, keyboard, and drums, but was not proficient in them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NME_446-0"><a href="#cite_note-NME-446">[443]</a></sup> When composing, he recorded ideas by beatboxing and imitating instruments vocally.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NME_446-1"><a href="#cite_note-NME-446">[443]</a></sup> Describing the process, he said: "I'll just sing the bass part into the tape recorder. I'll take that bass lick and put the chords of the melody over the bass lick and that's what inspires the melody." Engineer Robert Hoffman recalled that after Jackson came in with a song he had written overnight, Jackson sang every note of every chord to a guitar player. Hoffman also remembered Jackson singing string arrangements part by part into a cassette recorder.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NME_446-2"><a href="#cite_note-NME-446">[443]</a></sup>
</p><p><span class="anchor" id="Crotch_grab"></span>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Dance">Dance</span></h3>
<p>Jackson danced from a young age as part of the Jackson 5,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sanjoy_447-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sanjoy-447">[444]</a></sup> and incorporated dance extensively in his performances and music videos.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sanjoy_447-1"><a href="#cite_note-Sanjoy-447">[444]</a></sup> According to Sanjoy Roy of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i>, Jackson would "flick and retract his limbs like switchblades, or snap out of a tornado spin into a perfectly poised toe-stand".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sanjoy_447-2"><a href="#cite_note-Sanjoy-447">[444]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Moonwalk_(dance)" title="Moonwalk (dance)">moonwalk</a>, taught to him by <a href="/wiki/Jeffrey_Daniel" title="Jeffrey Daniel">Jeffrey Daniel</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Daniel_83-1"><a href="#cite_note-Daniel-83">[81]</a></sup> was Jackson's signature dance move and one of the most famous of the 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[445]</a></sup> Jackson is credited for coining the name "moonwalk"; the move was previously known as the "backslide".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[446]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-450"><a href="#cite_note-450">[447]</a></sup> His other moves included the <a href="/wiki/Robot_(dance)" title="Robot (dance)">robot</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMansour2005403_51-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMansour2005403-51">[49]</a></sup> crotch grab, and the "anti-gravity" lean of the "Smooth Criminal" video.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sanjoy_447-3"><a href="#cite_note-Sanjoy-447">[444]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Themes_and_genres">Themes and genres</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson1_1988.jpg"><img alt="Black and white photo of Jackson holding a microphone and singing." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Michael_Jackson1_1988.jpg/220px-Michael_Jackson1_1988.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Michael_Jackson1_1988.jpg/330px-Michael_Jackson1_1988.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Michael_Jackson1_1988.jpg/440px-Michael_Jackson1_1988.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson1_1988.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jackson during his <a href="/wiki/Bad_(tour)" title="Bad (tour)">Bad</a> tour in Vienna, June 1988</div></div></div>
<p>Jackson explored genres including pop,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_12-3"><a href="#cite_note-allmusic-12">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jet_451-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jet-451">[448]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Soul_music" title="Soul music">soul</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_12-4"><a href="#cite_note-allmusic-12">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bio2_159-2"><a href="#cite_note-Bio2-159">[157]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rhythm_and_blues" title="Rhythm and blues">rhythm and blues</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jet_451-1"><a href="#cite_note-Jet-451">[448]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Funk" title="Funk">funk</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Help_452-0"><a href="#cite_note-Help-452">[449]</a></sup> rock,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jet_451-2"><a href="#cite_note-Jet-451">[448]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Help_452-1"><a href="#cite_note-Help-452">[449]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Disco" title="Disco">disco</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AMOFW_453-0"><a href="#cite_note-AMOFW-453">[450]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Post-disco" title="Post-disco">post-disco</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Help_452-2"><a href="#cite_note-Help-452">[449]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Dance-pop" title="Dance-pop">dance-pop</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1995285_454-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1995285-454">[451]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/New_jack_swing" title="New jack swing">new jack swing</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_12-5"><a href="#cite_note-allmusic-12">[10]</a></sup> Steve Huey of <a href="/wiki/AllMusic" title="AllMusic">AllMusic</a> wrote that <i>Thriller</i> refined the strengths of <i>Off the Wall</i>; the dance and rock tracks were more aggressive, while the pop tunes and ballads were softer and more soulful.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_12-6"><a href="#cite_note-allmusic-12">[10]</a></sup> Its tracks included the ballads "The Lady in My Life", "<a href="/wiki/Human_Nature_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Human Nature (Michael Jackson song)">Human Nature</a>", and "<a href="/wiki/The_Girl_Is_Mine" title="The Girl Is Mine">The Girl Is Mine</a>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AMThriller_455-0"><a href="#cite_note-AMThriller-455">[452]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thriller_441-1"><a href="#cite_note-Thriller-441">[438]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Slant_456-0"><a href="#cite_note-Slant-456">[453]</a></sup> the funk pieces "Billie Jean" and "Wanna Be Startin' Somethin'",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AMThriller_455-1"><a href="#cite_note-AMThriller-455">[452]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thriller_441-2"><a href="#cite_note-Thriller-441">[438]</a></sup> and the disco set "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baby_Be_Mine_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Baby Be Mine (Michael Jackson song)">Baby Be Mine</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/P.Y.T._(Pretty_Young_Thing)" title="P.Y.T. (Pretty Young Thing)">P.Y.T. (Pretty Young Thing)</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Slant_456-1"><a href="#cite_note-Slant-456">[453]</a></sup>
</p><p>With <i>Off the Wall</i>, Jackson's "vocabulary of grunts, squeals, hiccups, moans, and asides" vividly showed his maturation into an adult, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Christgau" title="Robert Christgau">Robert Christgau</a> wrote in <i><a href="/wiki/Christgau%27s_Record_Guide:_Rock_Albums_of_the_Seventies" title="Christgau's Record Guide: Rock Albums of the Seventies">Christgau's Record Guide: Rock Albums of the Seventies</a></i> (1981). The album's title track suggested to the critic a parallel between Jackson and <a href="/wiki/Stevie_Wonder" title="Stevie Wonder">Stevie Wonder</a>'s "oddball" music personas: "Since childhood his main contact with the real world has been on stage and in bed."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChristgau1981Consumer_Guide_'70s:_J_457-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChristgau1981Consumer_Guide_'70s:_J-457">[454]</a></sup> With <i>Thriller</i>, Christopher Connelly of <i>Rolling Stone</i> commented that Jackson developed his long association with the subliminal theme of <a href="/wiki/Paranoia" title="Paranoia">paranoia</a> and darker imagery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thriller_441-3"><a href="#cite_note-Thriller-441">[438]</a></sup> AllMusic's <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Thomas_Erlewine" title="Stephen Thomas Erlewine">Stephen Thomas Erlewine</a> noted this on the songs "Billie Jean" and "Wanna Be Startin' Somethin'".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AMThriller_455-2"><a href="#cite_note-AMThriller-455">[452]</a></sup> In "Billie Jean", Jackson depicts an obsessive fan who alleges he has fathered her child,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_12-7"><a href="#cite_note-allmusic-12">[10]</a></sup> and in "Wanna Be Startin' Somethin'" he argues against gossip and the media.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thriller_441-4"><a href="#cite_note-Thriller-441">[438]</a></sup> "Beat It" decried gang violence in a homage to <i><a href="/wiki/West_Side_Story" title="West Side Story">West Side Story</a></i>, and was Jackson's first successful rock cross-over piece, according to Huey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_12-8"><a href="#cite_note-allmusic-12">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bio_43-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bio-43">[41]</a></sup> He observed that "<a href="/wiki/Thriller_(song)" title="Thriller (song)">Thriller</a>" began Jackson's interest with the theme of the <a href="/wiki/Supernatural" title="Supernatural">supernatural</a>, a topic he revisited in subsequent years. In 1985, Jackson co-wrote the charity anthem "We Are the World"; humanitarian themes later became a recurring theme in his lyrics and public persona.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_12-9"><a href="#cite_note-allmusic-12">[10]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1097025294">.mw-parser-output .side-box{margin:4px 0;box-sizing:border-box;border:1px solid #aaa;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em;background-color:#f9f9f9}.mw-parser-output .side-box-abovebelow,.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{padding:0.25em 0.9em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-image{padding:2px 0 2px 0.9em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-imageright{padding:2px 0.9em 2px 0;text-align:center}@media(min-width:500px){.mw-parser-output .side-box-flex{display:flex;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{flex:1}}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .side-box{width:238px}.mw-parser-output .side-box-right{clear:right;float:right;margin-left:1em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-left{margin-right:1em}}</style><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096940132">.mw-parser-output .listen .side-box-text{line-height:1.1em}.mw-parser-output .listen-plain{border:none;background:transparent}.mw-parser-output .listen-embedded{width:100%;margin:0;border-width:1px 0 0 0;background:transparent}.mw-parser-output .listen-header{padding:2px}.mw-parser-output .listen-embedded .listen-header{padding:2px 0}.mw-parser-output .listen-file-header{padding:4px 0}.mw-parser-output .listen .description{padding-top:2px}.mw-parser-output .listen .mw-tmh-player{max-width:100%}@media(max-width:719px){.mw-parser-output .listen{clear:both}}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .listen:not(.listen-noimage){width:320px}.mw-parser-output .listen-left{overflow:visible;float:left}.mw-parser-output .listen-center{float:none;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto}}</style><div class="side-box side-box-right listen noprint">
<div class="side-box-flex">
<div class="side-box-image"><div class="center"><div class="floatnone"><img alt="" data-file-height="160" data-file-width="160" decoding="async" height="50" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/75px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/100px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 2x" width="50"/></div></div></div>
<div class="side-box-text plainlist"><div class="haudio">
<div class="listen-file-header"><a href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_Thriller.ogg" title="File:Michael Jackson Thriller.ogg">"Thriller"</a></div>
<div><audio controls="" data-durationhint="26" data-mwprovider="local" data-mwtitle="Michael_Jackson_Thriller.ogg" id="mwe_player_0" preload="none" style="width:232px;" width="232"><source data-bandwidth="66350" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-title="Original Ogg file (66 kbps)" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/1/10/Michael_Jackson_Thriller.ogg" type='audio/ogg; codecs="vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="185888" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="MP3" data-title="MP3" data-transcodekey="mp3" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/transcoded/1/10/Michael_Jackson_Thriller.ogg/Michael_Jackson_Thriller.ogg.mp3" type="audio/mpeg"/><track data-dir="ltr" kind="subtitles" label="English ‪(en)‬" src="/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3AMichael_Jackson_Thriller.ogg&amp;lang=en&amp;trackformat=vtt" srclang="en" type="text/vtt"/></audio></div>
<div class="description">Jackson's song "Thriller", released as a single in 1984; Nelson George wrote that it uses cinematic sound effects, horror film motifs, and vocal trickery to convey a sense of danger.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGeorge200423_458-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGeorge200423-458">[455]</a></sup></div></div><hr/><div class="haudio">
<div class="listen-file-header"><a href="/wiki/File:Smooth_Criminal_by_Michael_Jackson.ogg" title="File:Smooth Criminal by Michael Jackson.ogg">"Smooth Criminal"</a></div>
<div><audio controls="" data-durationhint="28" data-mwprovider="local" data-mwtitle="Smooth_Criminal_by_Michael_Jackson.ogg" id="mwe_player_1" preload="none" style="width:232px;" width="232"><source data-bandwidth="69807" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-title="Original Ogg file (70 kbps)" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/6/68/Smooth_Criminal_by_Michael_Jackson.ogg" type='audio/ogg; codecs="vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="186592" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="MP3" data-title="MP3" data-transcodekey="mp3" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/transcoded/6/68/Smooth_Criminal_by_Michael_Jackson.ogg/Smooth_Criminal_by_Michael_Jackson.ogg.mp3" type="audio/mpeg"/><track data-dir="ltr" kind="subtitles" label="English ‪(en)‬" src="/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3ASmooth_Criminal_by_Michael_Jackson.ogg&amp;lang=en&amp;trackformat=vtt" srclang="en" type="text/vtt"/><track data-dir="ltr" kind="subtitles" label="español ‪(es)‬" src="/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3ASmooth_Criminal_by_Michael_Jackson.ogg&amp;lang=es&amp;trackformat=vtt" srclang="es" type="text/vtt"/></audio></div>
<div class="description">A single from the album <i>Bad</i>, released 1988, "Smooth Criminal" features digital drum sounds, keyboard bass, and other percussion elements; George said it gave the impression of a pulsing heart.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGeorge200424_459-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGeorge200424-459">[456]</a></sup></div></div><hr/><div class="haudio">
<div class="listen-file-header"><a href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_-_Black_Or_White.ogg" title="File:Michael Jackson - Black Or White.ogg">"Black or White"</a></div>
<div><audio controls="" data-durationhint="18" data-mwprovider="local" data-mwtitle="Michael_Jackson_-_Black_Or_White.ogg" id="mwe_player_2" preload="none" style="width:232px;" width="232"><source data-bandwidth="66808" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-title="Original Ogg file (67 kbps)" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/6/6f/Michael_Jackson_-_Black_Or_White.ogg" type='audio/ogg; codecs="vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="179600" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="MP3" data-title="MP3" data-transcodekey="mp3" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/transcoded/6/6f/Michael_Jackson_-_Black_Or_White.ogg/Michael_Jackson_-_Black_Or_White.ogg.mp3" type="audio/mpeg"/><track data-dir="ltr" kind="subtitles" label="English ‪(en)‬" src="/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3AMichael_Jackson_-_Black_Or_White.ogg&amp;lang=en&amp;trackformat=vtt" srclang="en" type="text/vtt"/></audio></div>
<div class="description">The lead single from <i>Dangerous</i>, "Black or White", is a danceable rock song with hard rock elements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460"><a href="#cite_note-460">[457]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERamageBeanJohnson2001491_461-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERamageBeanJohnson2001491-461">[458]</a></sup></div></div></div></div>
<div class="side-box-abovebelow"><hr/><i class="selfreference">Problems playing these files? See <a href="/wiki/Help:Media" title="Help:Media">media help</a>.</i></div>
</div>
<p>In <i>Bad</i>, Jackson's concept of the predatory lover is seen on the rock song "Dirty Diana".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-462"><a href="#cite_note-462">[459]</a></sup> The lead single "I Just Can't Stop Loving You" is a traditional love ballad, and "Man in the Mirror" is a ballad of confession and resolution. "<a href="/wiki/Smooth_Criminal" title="Smooth Criminal">Smooth Criminal</a>" is an evocation of bloody assault, rape and likely murder.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Time2_140-1"><a href="#cite_note-Time2-140">[138]</a></sup> AllMusic's Stephen Thomas Erlewine states that <i>Dangerous</i> presents Jackson as a paradoxical person.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dangerous_463-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dangerous-463">[460]</a></sup> The first half of the record is dedicated to new jack swing, including songs like "Jam" and "Remember the Time". It was the first Jackson album in which social ills became a primary theme; "Why You Wanna Trip on Me", for example, protests world hunger, AIDS, homelessness and drugs. <i>Dangerous</i> contains sexually charged songs such as "<a href="/wiki/In_the_Closet" title="In the Closet">In the Closet</a>". The title track continues the theme of the predatory lover and compulsive desire. The second half includes introspective, pop-gospel anthems such as "<a href="/wiki/Will_You_Be_There" title="Will You Be There">Will You Be There</a>", "Heal the World" and "Keep the Faith".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_Dangerous_442-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYT_Dangerous-442">[439]</a></sup> In the ballad "<a href="/wiki/Gone_Too_Soon" title="Gone Too Soon">Gone Too Soon</a>", Jackson gives tribute to Ryan White and the plight of those with AIDS.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-464"><a href="#cite_note-464">[461]</a></sup>
</p><p><i>HIStory</i> creates an atmosphere of paranoia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AMHIStory_465-0"><a href="#cite_note-AMHIStory-465">[462]</a></sup> In the new jack swing-funk rock tracks "Scream" and "Tabloid Junkie", and the R&amp;B ballad "<a href="/wiki/You_Are_Not_Alone" title="You Are Not Alone">You Are Not Alone</a>", Jackson retaliates against the injustice and isolation he feels, and directs his anger at the media.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RSHIStory_466-0"><a href="#cite_note-RSHIStory-466">[463]</a></sup> In the introspective ballad "<a href="/wiki/Stranger_in_Moscow" title="Stranger in Moscow">Stranger in Moscow</a>", Jackson laments his "fall from grace"; "Earth Song", "Childhood", "Little Susie" and "Smile" are operatic pop songs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AMHIStory_465-1"><a href="#cite_note-AMHIStory-465">[462]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RSHIStory_466-1"><a href="#cite_note-RSHIStory-466">[463]</a></sup> In "<a href="/wiki/D.S._(song)" title="D.S. (song)">D.S.</a>", Jackson attacks lawyer <a href="/wiki/Thomas_W._Sneddon_Jr." title="Thomas W. Sneddon Jr.">Thomas W. Sneddon Jr.</a>, who had prosecuted him in both child sexual abuse cases; he describes Sneddon as a white supremacist who wanted to "get my ass, dead or alive".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-467"><a href="#cite_note-467">[464]</a></sup> <i>Invincible</i> includes urban soul tracks such as "<a href="/wiki/Cry_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Cry (Michael Jackson song)">Cry</a>" and "The Lost Children", ballads such as "<a href="/wiki/Speechless_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Speechless (Michael Jackson song)">Speechless</a>", "Break of Dawn", and "Butterflies" and mixes hip hop, pop, and R&amp;B in "2000 Watts", "Heartbreaker" and "Invincible".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468"><a href="#cite_note-468">[465]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-469"><a href="#cite_note-469">[466]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music_videos_and_choreography">Music videos and choreography</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michaeljacksonphoto_drewcohen.JPG"><img alt="A man is singing into a microphone under a spotlight. He wears a blue open-neck shirt over a white T-shirt, and dark pants. There are two colorfully-dressed men on either side of him." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1980" data-file-width="1559" decoding="async" height="254" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Michaeljacksonphoto_drewcohen.JPG/200px-Michaeljacksonphoto_drewcohen.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Michaeljacksonphoto_drewcohen.JPG/300px-Michaeljacksonphoto_drewcohen.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Michaeljacksonphoto_drewcohen.JPG/400px-Michaeljacksonphoto_drewcohen.JPG 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michaeljacksonphoto_drewcohen.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jackson (center) performing a dance sequence of "<a href="/wiki/The_Way_You_Make_Me_Feel" title="The Way You Make Me Feel">The Way You Make Me Feel</a>" at the Bad tour in 1988</div></div></div>
<p>Jackson released "<a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson%27s_Thriller_(music_video)" title="Michael Jackson's Thriller (music video)">Thriller</a>", a 14-minute music video directed by <a href="/wiki/John_Landis" title="John Landis">John Landis</a>, in 1983.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Registry_470-0"><a href="#cite_note-Registry-470">[467]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Zombie" title="Zombie">zombie</a>-themed video "defined music videos and broke racial barriers" on <a href="/wiki/MTV" title="MTV">MTV</a>, which had launched two years earlier.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYoung200925_46-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYoung200925-46">[44]</a></sup> Before <i>Thriller</i>, Jackson struggled to receive coverage on MTV, allegedly because he was African American.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-471"><a href="#cite_note-471">[468]</a></sup> Pressure from CBS Records persuaded MTV to start showing "Billie Jean" and later "Beat It", which led to a lengthy partnership with Jackson, and helped other black music artists gain recognition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Video_472-0"><a href="#cite_note-Video-472">[469]</a></sup> The popularity of his videos on MTV helped the relatively new channel's viewing figures, and MTV's focus shifted toward pop and R&amp;B.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Video_472-1"><a href="#cite_note-Video-472">[469]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-473"><a href="#cite_note-473">[470]</a></sup> His performance on <i>Motown 25: Yesterday, Today, Forever</i> changed the scope of live stage shows, making it acceptable for artists to lip-sync to music video on stage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEInglis2006119,_127_474-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInglis2006119,_127-474">[471]</a></sup> The choreography in <i>Thriller</i> has been copied in <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_India" title="Cinema of India">Indian films</a> and <a href="/wiki/Thriller_(viral_video)" title="Thriller (viral video)">prisons in the Philippines</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-475"><a href="#cite_note-475">[472]</a></sup> <i>Thriller</i> marked an increase in scale for music videos, and was named the most successful music video ever by the <i>Guinness World Records</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-World_Records_223-1"><a href="#cite_note-World_Records-223">[221]</a></sup>
</p><p>In "Bad"'s 19-minute video—directed by <a href="/wiki/Martin_Scorsese" title="Martin Scorsese">Martin Scorsese</a>—Jackson used sexual imagery and choreography, and touched his chest, torso and crotch. When asked by Winfrey in the 1993 interview about why he grabbed his crotch, he said it was spontaneously compelled by the music. <i>Time</i> magazine described the "Bad" video as "infamous". It featured <a href="/wiki/Wesley_Snipes" title="Wesley Snipes">Wesley Snipes</a>; Jackson's later videos often featured famous cameo roles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009370–373_476-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaraborrelli2009370–373-476">[473]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-477"><a href="#cite_note-477">[474]</a></sup> For the "Smooth Criminal" video, Jackson experimented with leaning forward at a 45 degree angle, beyond the performer's center of gravity. To accomplish this live, Jackson and designers developed a special shoe to lock the performer's feet to the stage, allowing them to lean forward. They were granted <span><a class="external text" href="http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?patentnumber=5255452" rel="nofollow">U.S. Patent 5,255,452</a></span> for the device.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-478"><a href="#cite_note-478">[475]</a></sup> The video for "Leave Me Alone" was not officially released in the US, but in 1989 was nominated for three <i>Billboard</i> Music Video Awards<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbell1993273_479-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell1993273-479">[476]</a></sup> and won a Golden Lion Award for its special effects. It won a Grammy for <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Music_Video" title="Grammy Award for Best Music Video">Best Music Video, Short Form</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-grammy_mj_65-10"><a href="#cite_note-grammy_mj-65">[63]</a></sup>
</p><p>He received the <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson_Video_Vanguard_Award" title="Michael Jackson Video Vanguard Award">MTV Video Vanguard Award</a> in 1988; in 2001 the award was renamed in his honor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MTV2_480-0"><a href="#cite_note-MTV2-480">[477]</a></sup> The "Black or White" video simultaneously premiered on November 14, 1991, in 27 countries with an estimated audience of 500<span class="nowrap"> </span>million people, the largest audience ever for a music video at the time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Achievements_174-4"><a href="#cite_note-Achievements-174">[172]</a></sup> Along with Jackson, it featured <a href="/wiki/Macaulay_Culkin" title="Macaulay Culkin">Macaulay Culkin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peggy_Lipton" title="Peggy Lipton">Peggy Lipton</a>, and <a href="/wiki/George_Wendt" title="George Wendt">George Wendt</a>. It helped introduce <a href="/wiki/Morphing" title="Morphing">morphing</a> to music videos.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbell1993303_481-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell1993303-481">[478]</a></sup> It was controversial for scenes in which Jackson rubs his crotch, vandalizes cars, and throws a garbage can through a storefront. He apologized and removed the final scene of the video.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ew1991_163-1"><a href="#cite_note-ew1991-163">[161]</a></sup>
</p><p>"In the Closet" featured <a href="/wiki/Naomi_Campbell" title="Naomi Campbell">Naomi Campbell</a> in a courtship dance with Jackson.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-482"><a href="#cite_note-482">[479]</a></sup> "Remember the Time" was set in <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">ancient Egypt</a>, and featured <a href="/wiki/Eddie_Murphy" title="Eddie Murphy">Eddie Murphy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iman_(model)" title="Iman (model)">Iman</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Magic_Johnson" title="Magic Johnson">Magic Johnson</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbell1993313–314_483-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell1993313–314-483">[480]</a></sup> The video for "Scream", directed by <a href="/wiki/Mark_Romanek" title="Mark Romanek">Mark Romanek</a> and production designer Tom Foden, gained a record 11 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MTV_Video_Music_Award" title="MTV Video Music Award">MTV Video Music Award</a> Nominations, and won "Best Dance Video", "Best Choreography", and "Best Art Direction".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBoepple199552_484-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBoepple199552-484">[481]</a></sup> The song and its video are Jackson's response to being accused of child molestation in 1993.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-485"><a href="#cite_note-485">[482]</a></sup> A year later, it won a Grammy for Best Music Video, Short Form. It has been reported as the <a href="/wiki/List_of_most_expensive_music_videos" title="List of most expensive music videos">most expensive music video ever made</a>, at $7<span class="nowrap"> </span>million;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-486"><a href="#cite_note-486">[483]</a></sup> Romanek has contradicted this.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-487"><a href="#cite_note-487">[484]</a></sup> The "Earth Song" video was nominated for the 1997 Grammy for Best Music Video, Short Form.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-488"><a href="#cite_note-488">[485]</a></sup>
</p><p><i><a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson%27s_Ghosts" title="Michael Jackson's Ghosts">Michael Jackson's Ghosts</a>,</i> a short film written by Jackson and <a href="/wiki/Stephen_King" title="Stephen King">Stephen King</a> and directed by <a href="/wiki/Stan_Winston" title="Stan Winston">Stan Winston</a>, premiered at the 1996 <a href="/wiki/Cannes_Film_Festival" title="Cannes Film Festival">Cannes Film Festival</a>. At over 38 minutes long, it held the Guinness world record for the longest music video until 2013, when it was eclipsed by the video for the <a href="/wiki/Pharrell_Williams" title="Pharrell Williams">Pharrell Williams</a> song "<a href="/wiki/Happy_(Pharrell_Williams_song)" title="Happy (Pharrell Williams song)">Happy</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-489"><a href="#cite_note-489">[486]</a></sup> The 2001 video for "<a href="/wiki/You_Rock_My_World" title="You Rock My World">You Rock My World</a>" lasts over 13 minutes, was directed by <a href="/wiki/Paul_Hunter_(director)" title="Paul Hunter (director)">Paul Hunter</a>, and features <a href="/wiki/Chris_Tucker" title="Chris Tucker">Chris Tucker</a> and <a href="/wiki/Marlon_Brando" title="Marlon Brando">Marlon Brando</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-490"><a href="#cite_note-490">[487]</a></sup> It won an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NAACP_Image_Award" title="NAACP Image Award">NAACP Image Award</a> for Outstanding Music Video in 2002.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-491"><a href="#cite_note-491">[488]</a></sup>
</p><p>In December 2009, the <a href="/wiki/Library_of_Congress" title="Library of Congress">Library of Congress</a> selected "Thriller" as the only music video to be preserved in the <a href="/wiki/National_Film_Registry" title="National Film Registry">National Film Registry</a>, as a work of "enduring importance to American culture".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-492"><a href="#cite_note-492">[489]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_493-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-493">[490]</a></sup> Huey wrote that Jackson transformed the music video into an artform and a promotional tool through complex story lines, dance routines, special effects and famous cameos, while breaking down racial barriers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_12-10"><a href="#cite_note-allmusic-12">[10]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Honors_and_awards">Honors and awards</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_awards_and_nominations_received_by_Michael_Jackson" title="List of awards and nominations received by Michael Jackson">List of awards and nominations received by Michael Jackson</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:162px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Thriller_platinum_record,_Hard_Rock_Cafe_Hollywood.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1777" data-file-width="1435" decoding="async" height="198" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Thriller_platinum_record%2C_Hard_Rock_Cafe_Hollywood.JPG/160px-Thriller_platinum_record%2C_Hard_Rock_Cafe_Hollywood.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Thriller_platinum_record%2C_Hard_Rock_Cafe_Hollywood.JPG/240px-Thriller_platinum_record%2C_Hard_Rock_Cafe_Hollywood.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Thriller_platinum_record%2C_Hard_Rock_Cafe_Hollywood.JPG/320px-Thriller_platinum_record%2C_Hard_Rock_Cafe_Hollywood.JPG 2x" width="160"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Thriller_platinum_record,_Hard_Rock_Cafe_Hollywood.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <i>Thriller</i> <a href="/wiki/RIAA_certification" title="RIAA certification">platinum</a> certified record on display at the <a href="/wiki/Hard_Rock_Cafe" title="Hard Rock Cafe">Hard Rock Cafe</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hollywood,_Los_Angeles" title="Hollywood, Los Angeles">Hollywood</a>. As of 2017, it is certified 33× platinum.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Certified_345-1"><a href="#cite_note-Certified-345">[343]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Jackson is one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_music_artists" title="List of best-selling music artists">best-selling music artists</a> in history,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-494"><a href="#cite_note-494">[491]</a></sup> with sales estimated by various sources up to 400 million – 1 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-495"><a href="#cite_note-495">[492]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="ref_Note_2"><a href="#endnote_Note_2">[Note 2]</a></sup> He had 13 <a href="/wiki/List_of_artists_who_reached_number_one_in_the_United_States#J" title="List of artists who reached number one in the United States">number-one singles in the US</a> in his solo career—more than any other male artist in the Hot 100 era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-496"><a href="#cite_note-496">[493]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Recording_Industry_Association_of_America" title="Recording Industry Association of America">RIAA</a> regards him as the biggest-selling music artist of all time worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RIAA_8-2"><a href="#cite_note-RIAA-8">[7]</a></sup> He was invited and honored by a <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">President of the United States</a> at the <a href="/wiki/White_House" title="White House">White House</a> three times. In 1984, he was honored with a "Presidential Public Safety Commendation" award by <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a> for his humanitarian endeavors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-497"><a href="#cite_note-497">[494]</a></sup> In 1990, he was honored as the "Artist of the Decade" by <a href="/wiki/George_H._W._Bush" title="George H. W. Bush">George H. W. Bush</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGeorge200444–45_498-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGeorge200444–45-498">[495]</a></sup> In 1992, he was honored as a "Point of Light Ambassador" by Bush for inviting disadvantaged children to his <a href="/wiki/Neverland_Ranch" title="Neverland Ranch">Neverland Ranch</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbell1993321_499-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell1993321-499">[496]</a></sup>
</p><p>He won <a href="/wiki/List_of_awards_and_nominations_received_by_Michael_Jackson" title="List of awards and nominations received by Michael Jackson">hundreds of awards</a>, more than any other popular music recording artist.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-500"><a href="#cite_note-500">[497]</a></sup> His awards include 39 Guinness World Records, including the Most Successful Entertainer of All Time,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CityNews_405-1"><a href="#cite_note-CityNews-405">[402]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ditzian_406-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ditzian-406">[403]</a></sup> 13 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grammy_Award" title="Grammy Award">Grammy Awards</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-501"><a href="#cite_note-501">[498]</a></sup> as well as the <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Legend_Award" title="Grammy Legend Award">Grammy Legend Award</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-502"><a href="#cite_note-502">[499]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Lifetime_Achievement_Award" title="Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award">Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-503"><a href="#cite_note-503">[500]</a></sup> and a record 26 American Music Awards, including the "Artist of the Century" and "Artist of the 1980s".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MTV_242-1"><a href="#cite_note-MTV-242">[240]</a></sup> He also received the <a href="/wiki/World_Music_Awards" title="World Music Awards">World Music Awards</a>' Best-Selling Pop Male Artist of the Millennium and the <a href="/wiki/Bambi_Award" title="Bambi Award">Bambi</a> Pop Artist of the Millennium Award.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-504"><a href="#cite_note-504">[501]</a></sup> Jackson was inducted onto the <a href="/wiki/Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame" title="Hollywood Walk of Fame">Hollywood Walk of Fame</a> in 1980 as a member of the Jacksons, and in 1984 as a solo artist. He was <a href="/wiki/List_of_Rock_and_Roll_Hall_of_Fame_inductees#Performers" title="List of Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inductees">inducted to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vocal_Group_Hall_of_Fame" title="Vocal Group Hall of Fame">Vocal Group Hall of Fame</a> as a member of The Jackson 5 in 1997 and 1999,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-505"><a href="#cite_note-505">[502]</a></sup> respectively, and again as a solo artist in 2001.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-506"><a href="#cite_note-506">[503]</a></sup> In 2002, he was added to the <a href="/wiki/Songwriters_Hall_of_Fame" title="Songwriters Hall of Fame">Songwriters Hall of Fame</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-507"><a href="#cite_note-507">[504]</a></sup> In 2010, he was the first recording artist to be inducted into the <a href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_Dance_and_Hall_of_Fame" title="National Museum of Dance and Hall of Fame">Dance Hall of Fame</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-508"><a href="#cite_note-508">[505]</a></sup> and in 2014, he was posthumously inducted into the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rhythm_and_Blues_Music_Hall_of_Fame" title="Rhythm and Blues Music Hall of Fame">Rhythm and Blues Music Hall of Fame</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-509"><a href="#cite_note-509">[506]</a></sup> In 2021, he was among the inaugural inductees into the <a href="/wiki/Black_Music_%26_Entertainment_Walk_of_Fame" title="Black Music &amp; Entertainment Walk of Fame">Black Music &amp; Entertainment Walk of Fame</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-510"><a href="#cite_note-510">[507]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1988, <a href="/wiki/Fisk_University" title="Fisk University">Fisk University</a> honored him with an Honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-511"><a href="#cite_note-511">[508]</a></sup> In 1992, he was invested as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Title_of_honour" title="Title of honour">titular king</a> of <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Sanwi" title="Kingdom of Sanwi">Sanwi</a>, a traditional <a href="/wiki/Monarchy" title="Monarchy">kingdom</a> located in the south-east of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ivory_Coast" title="Republic of Ivory Coast">Ivory Coast</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-512"><a href="#cite_note-512">[509]</a></sup> In July 2009, the Lunar Republic Society named a crater on the Moon after Jackson.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-513"><a href="#cite_note-513">[510]</a></sup> In August, for what would have been Jackson's 51st birthday, Google dedicated their <a href="/wiki/Google_Doodle" title="Google Doodle">Google Doodle</a> to him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-514"><a href="#cite_note-514">[511]</a></sup> In 2012, the extinct hermit crab <i><a href="/wiki/Mesoparapylocheles_michaeljacksoni" title="Mesoparapylocheles michaeljacksoni">Mesoparapylocheles michaeljacksoni</a></i> was named in his honor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-515"><a href="#cite_note-515">[512]</a></sup> In 2014, the <a href="/wiki/British_Council" title="British Council">British Council</a> of Cultural Relations deemed Jackson's life one of the 80 most important cultural moments of the 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-516"><a href="#cite_note-516">[513]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/World_Vitiligo_Day" title="World Vitiligo Day">World Vitiligo Day</a> has been celebrated on June 25, the anniversary of Jackson's death, to raise awareness of the auto-immune disorder that Jackson suffered from.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-517"><a href="#cite_note-517">[514]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Earnings">Earnings</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Estate_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Estate of Michael Jackson">Estate of Michael Jackson</a></div>
<p>In 1989, Jackson's annual earnings from album sales, endorsements, and concerts were estimated at $125<span class="nowrap"> </span>million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-World_Records_223-2"><a href="#cite_note-World_Records-223">[221]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Forbes" title="Forbes">Forbes</a></i> placed Jackson's annual income at $35<span class="nowrap"> </span>million in 1996 and $20<span class="nowrap"> </span>million in 1997.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Finances_518-0"><a href="#cite_note-Finances-518">[515]</a></sup> Estimates of Jackson's net worth during his life range from negative $285<span class="nowrap"> </span>million to positive $350<span class="nowrap"> </span>million for 2002, 2003 and 2007.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-519"><a href="#cite_note-519">[516]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-520"><a href="#cite_note-520">[517]</a></sup> <i>Forbes</i> reported in August 2018 that Jackson's total career pretax earnings in life and death were $4.2<span class="nowrap"> </span>billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-521"><a href="#cite_note-521">[518]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-522"><a href="#cite_note-522">[519]</a></sup> Sales of his recordings through Sony's music unit earned him an estimated $300<span class="nowrap"> </span>million in royalties. He may have earned another $400<span class="nowrap"> </span>million from concerts, music publishing (including his share of the Beatles catalog), endorsements, merchandising and music videos.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-523"><a href="#cite_note-523">[520]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2013, the executors of Jackson's estate filed a petition in the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Tax_Court" title="United States Tax Court">United States Tax Court</a> as a result of a dispute with the <a href="/wiki/Internal_Revenue_Service" title="Internal Revenue Service">Internal Revenue Service</a> (IRS) over <a href="/wiki/Estate_tax_in_the_United_States" title="Estate tax in the United States">US federal estate taxes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-524"><a href="#cite_note-524">[521]</a></sup> The executors claim that it was worth about $7<span class="nowrap"> </span>million, the IRS that it was worth over $1.1<span class="nowrap"> </span>billion. In February 2014, the IRS reported that Jackson's estate owed $702<span class="nowrap"> </span>million; $505<span class="nowrap"> </span>million in taxes, and $197<span class="nowrap"> </span>million in penalties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gottlieb_525-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gottlieb-525">[522]</a></sup> A trial was held from February 6 to 24, 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-526"><a href="#cite_note-526">[523]</a></sup> In 2021, the Tax Court issued a ruling in favor of the estate, ruling that the estate's total combined value of the estate was $111.5 million and that the value of Jackson's name and likeness was $4 million (not the $61 million estimated by the IRS's outside expert witness).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-527"><a href="#cite_note-527">[524]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2016, <i>Forbes</i> estimated annual gross earnings by the Jackson Estate at $825<span class="nowrap"> </span>million, the largest ever recorded for a celebrity, mostly due to the sale of the Sony/ATV catalog.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Forbes2016_528-0"><a href="#cite_note-Forbes2016-528">[525]</a></sup> In 2018, the figure was $400<span class="nowrap"> </span>million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Forbes2018_529-0"><a href="#cite_note-Forbes2018-529">[526]</a></sup> It was the eighth year since his death that Jackson's annual earnings were reported to be over $100<span class="nowrap"> </span>million, thus bringing Jackson's postmortem total to $2.4<span class="nowrap"> </span>billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-530"><a href="#cite_note-530">[527]</a></sup> In 2020, <i>Forbes</i> recognized Jackson as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Forbes%27_list_of_the_world%27s_highest-paid_dead_celebrity" title="Forbes' list of the world's highest-paid dead celebrity">top-earning dead celebrity</a> each year since his death except 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-531"><a href="#cite_note-531">[528]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-532"><a href="#cite_note-532">[529]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Discography">Discography</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson_albums_discography" title="Michael Jackson albums discography">Michael Jackson albums discography</a> and <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson_singles_discography" title="Michael Jackson singles discography">Michael Jackson singles discography</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/The_Jackson_5_discography" title="The Jackson 5 discography">The Jackson 5 discography</a></div>
<ul><li><i><a href="/wiki/Got_to_Be_There" title="Got to Be There">Got to Be There</a></i> (1972)</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Ben_(Michael_Jackson_album)" title="Ben (Michael Jackson album)">Ben</a></i> (1972)</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Music_%26_Me" title="Music &amp; Me">Music &amp; Me</a></i> (1973)</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Forever,_Michael" title="Forever, Michael">Forever, Michael</a></i> (1975)</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Off_the_Wall" title="Off the Wall">Off the Wall</a></i> (1979)</li>
